(\u00c5)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>(1)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(2)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(3)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>3727.09\u00a0</td><td>1.78\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>3729.88\u00a0</td><td>1.78\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>H\u03b4\u00a0</td><td>4102.89\u00a0</td><td>1.52\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>H\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>4341.68\u00a0</td><td>1.38\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>H\u03b2\u00a0</td><td>4862.68\u00a0</td><td>1.13\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>\u00a0</td><td>4960.30\u00a0</td><td>1.09\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>\u00a0</td><td>5008.24\u00a0</td><td>1.07\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>6549.86\u00a0</td><td>0.58\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>H\u03b1\u00a0</td><td>6564.61\u00a0</td><td>0.58\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>6585.27\u00a0</td><td>0.57\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>6718.29\u00a0</td><td>0.54\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>6732.68\u00a0</td><td>0.54\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201672681\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Detections that contained only an [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet were rejected if the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet was located in a region near a sky emission-line. Multiline detections were modelled using a Gaussian, and detections that included both [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u20095007 and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u20094959 emission-lines were scanned for a characteristic\u00a0\u223c\u00a03-to-1 ratio of the flux, respectively. All three multiline or greater hits were also visually inspected. Single-line detections were modelled with double Gaussian functions in order to scan for resolved [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublets. We inspected 1659 multiline \u2018hits\u2019 and 9762 single-line \u2018hits\u2019 that contained either the form of an [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet, or contained multiple patterns of background emission-lines. Each of these hits were graded as good. However, a large fraction of the single-line hits within a particular galaxy are not correlated in either redshift or spatially across the IFU and therefore drop out during the source-plane inspection process. Furthermore, detections that were geometrically positioned beyond the estimated strong lensing regime (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>) were discarded as non-candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We provide example plots of some of the multiline and single-line detections in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, showing the flux, best-fitting model, and Gaussian fits, including the observed emission-lines, as described in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"201672685\" scrollto-destination=\"201672685\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=mWiI5gl0Drtp0zUhW3pIKmkgO6999MxUCBIvQjspcpb3Jm9V93lSbaYR1SWJlhkkuzcbDQBfok3GkB8RE3-ax~cI0aPqR4RId~l5hS9ecXBBAVa-TNbegUpEAA92ZO8-teTHQaHOSHwLJTHPlzwo~bL6D87nlVFfBwPYnqIF7gN7lkdKGE88HDdgS335jKccXmL2P~eU9N8-vDrXQgpMJjg3DuKQuJdQPw4TfvHzYCms3qpV6vdEnASm2EpOl24UqJ4EC~b9fXikHiQJvynrRRrwyvofBx0itw13hRgI6ilqtKFOyZK6atYTmBalsZ4OvAfb5ziKXZwrHpUhFGkinQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Example plots of typical multiline and single-line detections. J1640+3919\u00a0</td><td>Single-line\u00a0</td><td>Resolved [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet.\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>System name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Detection mode<span aria-hidden=\"true\" aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(2)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(3)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SDSS J1123+5111\u00a0</td><td>Multiline\u00a0</td><td>Resolved [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet, H\u03b1, H\u03b2, [N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>a], and [S\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>b].\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1307+4618\u00a0</td><td>Multiline\u00a0</td><td>Strong [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>a] and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>b] with a characteristic 3:1 ratio.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0845+5357\u00a0</td><td>Multiline\u00a0</td><td>Resolved [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet, H\u03b1, and N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>a.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1640+3919\u00a0</td><td>Single-line\u00a0</td><td>Resolved [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet.\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201672687\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As in previous discovery programmes (including SLACS and BELLS), these background emission-line detections provide compelling evidence that follow-up imaging will confirm the existence of strong gravitational lenses. But we can go farther in our inspection than was previously possible with the single spectroscopic observation of SDSS and BOSS, by combining an estimate of the Einstein radius, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>, with the geometric information with a source-plane inspection, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201672690 id=\"201672690\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Einstein Radius Estimation</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">MaNGA data allows us to use spatial information to classify our candidate lens systems. For strong lenses with a density profile close to isothermal, such as SLACS lenses (Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), we expect strongly lensed images to lie within a circular region with radius equal to twice the Einstein radius of the lens. Although the most accurate measurement of the Einstein radius is derived by fitting a lens model to high-resolution imaging data, we do not have a complete set of follow-up imaging for our catalogue to model. Instead, we estimate the Einstein radius, using <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\r\n\\begin{eqnarray}\r\nR_{\\mathrm{Ein}} = \\sqrt{\\frac{4GM}{c^2}\\frac{D_{{\\rm LS}}}{D_{\\rm L} D_{\\rm S}}}\r\n\\end{eqnarray}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>where <em>M</em> is the enclosed mass, and <em>D<sub>L</sub></em> and <em>D<sub>S</sub></em> are cosmological angular diameter distances from observer to the lens and observer to the source, respectively.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The computation of the Einstein radius requires surface mass density maps for the galaxy, which we obtained from the publicly available MaNGA Firefly value-added catalogue (VAC, Wilkinson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) released with SDSS-IV DR14 (SDSS Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). In this VAC the input stellar population models of Maraston &amp; Str\u00f6mb\u00e4ck (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) are used, based on the MILES stellar library, with Kroupa IMF (Kroupa <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). We computed both a lower limit and an upper limit for the Einstein radius. For the lower limit of the Einstein radius, we computed the stellar mass enclosed within the lower-bound of the error provided by Firefly, but added no dark matter. For the upper limit, we computed the enclosed stellar mass within the upper-bound of the error provided by Firefly, and included a dark matter fraction computed using the theoretical model for the local stellar mass fraction of Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) at values of the ratio <em>R</em>/<em>R</em><sub>eff</sub>, where <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> is the effective radius from the NSA catalogue. We computed the mass, <em>M</em>, enclosed within a distance, <em>R</em>, and the Einstein radius, <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>, iteratively using equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ4\"></span><a href=\"#equ4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>), until we obtained a <em>R</em>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> solution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We compared the distribution of the Einstein radii of the SILO candidates to the published distribution of the Einstein radii of the grade A, B, and C lenses in the SLACS and BELLS surveys. As displayed in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, the Einstein radius distributions of the SLACS and BELLS surveys peak at \u223c0.6 and 1.0\u2009arcsec, with upper limits up to \u223c1.8 and 2.2\u2009arcsec, respectively. The distribution of the Einstein radii for the SILO candidates peaks at \u223c1.4 and 2.6\u2009arcsec, and the range extends up to \u223c3\u2009arcsec.</p>                        <a id=\"201672695\" scrollto-destination=\"201672695\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=0u7ll3kaCT15xqKCSZqCLYbAwnt7~TfVjNexsSK63TQadk~veTWcdHqr5aDYZWklJSANAW9rn18JW2JlGaV22mcCeQ0bef40L~aBT7c8jqUU4Wq-lYEsUhg53oriu9u02V76T8a9sRDBUoLh5iJRDGZp12hZwQfowgPcGBBCbxShskMq5vkl4npG4oq4XtkMynXIC8ghIIZKwYkgJq5Jw06OZKz0RjEQYCf40XUI4J7-YKSD4LZxAz3A9cc~aFOI6abRD9AkoWAOKQTrFSW-VLNmA9lAsAblXVJtQRIcXwTpQUtvCcypoFRZNIrPTp6GG99Q6x6BY4EiC2wfG3fRww__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of the Einstein radii. The grade A, B, and C lenses from the SLACS (large hatched region in purple) and the BELLS (small hatched region in green) surveys are compared with the Einstein radii of the lens candidates from the SILO survey (solid blue).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672695/sty653fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672695\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&Signature=bNNGYHBeSTNO6MCxny1X-XTzNHL~gndeDaopbCHZ8uhGRrJLGA6rdxKXcLbaN1T5afgbbdTCAS2m7aZz0NzDbff9gQ9-Ut4uLXSiZBPEGqfPkXhsoUhhxZ8yv5fj7ATLfNbyQGpdPNRKKoV20Wfq34IYcGsAUg4S01a0jz736e8mxWC0~yCkJzEAAaxWvznmW8hmsJozv5BiNvnJqYcVKQ8-~DM0EorXcMnjIOheBTifIdJtHjwjkvFg7g1whvGkxGgX0M4RQ3U~WT2GO9whJj-ggqj1GQbo9LewBkr05oXRWJyiGjNX0hLq-PrAucxce6cw0uysrAgb2ohcX~ufMg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201672695&ar=4925911&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of the Einstein radii. The grade A, B, and C lenses from the SLACS (large hatched region in purple) and the BELLS (small hatched region in green) surveys are compared with the Einstein radii of the lens candidates from the SILO survey (solid blue).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=0u7ll3kaCT15xqKCSZqCLYbAwnt7~TfVjNexsSK63TQadk~veTWcdHqr5aDYZWklJSANAW9rn18JW2JlGaV22mcCeQ0bef40L~aBT7c8jqUU4Wq-lYEsUhg53oriu9u02V76T8a9sRDBUoLh5iJRDGZp12hZwQfowgPcGBBCbxShskMq5vkl4npG4oq4XtkMynXIC8ghIIZKwYkgJq5Jw06OZKz0RjEQYCf40XUI4J7-YKSD4LZxAz3A9cc~aFOI6abRD9AkoWAOKQTrFSW-VLNmA9lAsAblXVJtQRIcXwTpQUtvCcypoFRZNIrPTp6GG99Q6x6BY4EiC2wfG3fRww__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of the Einstein radii. The grade A, B, and C lenses from the SLACS (large hatched region in purple) and the BELLS (small hatched region in green) surveys are compared with the Einstein radii of the lens candidates from the SILO survey (solid blue).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672695/sty653fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672695\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&Signature=bNNGYHBeSTNO6MCxny1X-XTzNHL~gndeDaopbCHZ8uhGRrJLGA6rdxKXcLbaN1T5afgbbdTCAS2m7aZz0NzDbff9gQ9-Ut4uLXSiZBPEGqfPkXhsoUhhxZ8yv5fj7ATLfNbyQGpdPNRKKoV20Wfq34IYcGsAUg4S01a0jz736e8mxWC0~yCkJzEAAaxWvznmW8hmsJozv5BiNvnJqYcVKQ8-~DM0EorXcMnjIOheBTifIdJtHjwjkvFg7g1whvGkxGgX0M4RQ3U~WT2GO9whJj-ggqj1GQbo9LewBkr05oXRWJyiGjNX0hLq-PrAucxce6cw0uysrAgb2ohcX~ufMg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201672695&ar=4925911&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of the Einstein radii. The grade A, B, and C lenses from the SLACS (large hatched region in purple) and the BELLS (small hatched region in green) surveys are compared with the Einstein radii of the lens candidates from the SILO survey (solid blue).</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201672696 id=\"201672696\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4>3.4 Source-plane inspection</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Whereas the BOSS and SDSS-I galaxies were observed with one fibre yielding a single spectrum containing all of the light from the galaxy, each MaNGA galaxy was observed with a fibre bundle, in which each fibre yielded multiple spectra from multiple exposures. This allows the candidate background emission-lines to be spatially correlated, increasing our confidence that the background emission-lines are real.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to determine whether the individual background emission-line hits discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a> originated in a common background source-plane, a finely spaced redshift grid (\u0394<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.05) was constructed and the hits for each galaxy were counted per spacing in the redshift grid. The background redshift, <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>, was selected from one of the good hits, limited to a precision of three decimal places, to allow for the variation due to internal radial motion of the background galaxy. Each MaNGA galaxy that contained at least two good hits in a source-plane was manually inspected to check for spatial correlation in the emission-line features. Since the background emission-lines in one hit can often be observed in surrounding fibres, we also inspected the source-planes that contained one good hit with three or more multilines, or one good single-line hit within a MaNGA galaxy that contained another source-plane with at least two good hits. These search methods identified a total of 1139 good multiline and 1926 good single-line hits, for a total of 3065. We inspected 397 background source-planes that contained at least two good hits. We inspected an additional 44 source-planes with a single multiline hit and 257 source-planes with a single-line hit.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The following selection criteria were applied to select the strong-lensing candidates from the source-planes:</p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The source-plane contained at least one multiline hit with a minimum of three emission-lines, or</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Each source-plane contained at least two (single-line or multiline) hits, or</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The source-plane contained at least one (single-line or multiline) hit with additional evidence of low S/N emission-lines that are correlated with the source-plane redshift, and are contained within fibres that are positioned near the hit.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The source-plane contained at least one background emission-line detected at a position within twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">We made an exception for system SDSS J0733+4411, SDSS J0825+1728, and SDSS J1307+4618, since each displayed well formed lensing features (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>). After applying these selections, we found 36 promising candidates out of which 2 showed evidence for compound lensing with multiple source-planes (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>). This final sample is presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"201672702\" scrollto-destination=\"201672702\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Candidate strong gravitational lenses. This is the list of strong gravitational lens candidates, discovered in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a> that further demonstrated background emission-lines at a common redshift (source-plane) within the strong lensing regime as discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>. Column 1 provides the SDSS System Name in terms of truncated J2000 RA and Dec. in the format HHMMSS.ss\u00b1DDMMSS.s. A dagger represents if the candidate is displayed as a narrow-band image within this paper. Column 2 provides the Plate-IFU of the galaxy observation. Column 3 provides the foreground spectroscopic redshift defined as the mean inner spectroscopic redshift, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_\\mathrm{F} = {\\bar{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}}$|\u2060</span>, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>. Column 4 provides the spectroscopically detected background emission-line source redshift, <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>, computed as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>. Column 5 provides the NSA S\u00e9rsic effective radius. Column 6 provides the Einstein radius with upper and lower limits. Column 7 provides the number of good background emission-line hits identified within the common source-plane. For those source-planes with only a single hit, we distinguish the case from one multiline hit (identified by a \u2020) from the case of one single-line hit (identified by *). Column 8 provides the ratio of the radial distance of a source-plane image's detectable edge to the estimated upper limit of the Einstein radius.</p></div> </div><div class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201672702\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Candidate strong gravitational lenses. This is the list of strong gravitational lens candidates, discovered in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a> that further demonstrated background emission-lines at a common redshift (source-plane) within the strong lensing regime as discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>. Column 1 provides the SDSS System Name in terms of truncated J2000 RA and Dec. in the format HHMMSS.ss\u00b1DDMMSS.s. A dagger represents if the candidate is displayed as a narrow-band image within this paper. Column 2 provides the Plate-IFU of the galaxy observation. Column 3 provides the foreground spectroscopic redshift defined as the mean inner spectroscopic redshift, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_\\mathrm{F} = {\\bar{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}}$|\u2060</span>, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>. Column 4 provides the spectroscopically detected background emission-line source redshift, <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>, computed as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>. Column 5 provides the NSA S\u00e9rsic effective radius. Column 6 provides the Einstein radius with upper and lower limits. Column 7 provides the number of good background emission-line hits identified within the common source-plane. For those source-planes with only a single hit, we distinguish the case from one multiline hit (identified by a \u2020) from the case of one single-line hit (identified by *). Column 8 provides the ratio of the radial distance of a source-plane image's detectable edge to the estimated upper limit of the Einstein radius.</p></div> </div><div J221101.52+122227.49\u00a0</td><td>7977\u20136102\u00a0</td><td>0.06139\u00a0</td><td>0.775\u00a0</td><td>12.06\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.86_{-1.34}^{+0.28}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>1*\u00a0</td><td>1.80\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201672702\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> provides two-dimensional plots of each of these 36 candidate lenses, showing each of the above selection criteria including the positions of the high S/N emission-line hits, and the location of the manually confirmed evidence of low S/N emission-lines from the background source. The plots also show the upper limit of the Einstein radii and the colour-scale of the square markers indicates the gravitational lensing convergence, computed as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\r\n\\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\kappa = \\Sigma /\\Sigma _{{\\rm cr}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>in order to indicate the strong lensing regime where \u03ba \u2273 1, where \u03a3 is the surface-mass density determined from the MaNGA Firefly VAC discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>, and <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\r\n\\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\Sigma _{{\\rm cr}} = \\frac{c^2}{4\\pi G} \\frac{D_{\\mathrm{S}}}{D_{\\mathrm{L}} D_{\\mathrm{L}S}}\r\n\\end{eqnarray}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div>is the critical surface-mass density.</div>                        <a id=\"201672704\" scrollto-destination=\"201672704\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig4a.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=UtLxp2TFp26we-ie3WFsxRuS39m3v5LJVhlJ6shmZCIO9mQx0p0DsjRfPhdnZk6u70YBYQaVJCUdblHEbabykU-K9aziwn-v6e2-ZRy0-AsjA0CjUiXGyil13VWcScoQnnPaoE6OJ7nBoAt9N6ryd0T4DzDWARq4428ojyXs7fggOzwojDi2KKn1uF9RAZEgvQoZ6R9B~eJRgWVoOjktbeBYZjjHIGfj1ezJiHT~uHFD1zgrgU~VrrDbvGBV8qkJUm1bAaC-m9MbN7ziyW1oBKgilI4QRAXrkQsjKIQ30mDSZtqHwoBZljzQezYaeYqEHDdv77WBCiRbWj7ej~M-IQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Plots of background emission line hits for each SILO candidate. The positions of the hits are shown with cyan numbers representing the good hit count, and the cyan triangles show the location of the manually confirmed evidence of low S/N background emission-lines. The inner and outer radii of the cyan circle represent the lower and upper limits of the Einstein radius. The green coloured circle represents twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius, and thus the upper limit of the strong lensing regime. The value of the gravitational lensing convergence, \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3cr, according to equation (5), is plotted with squares with respect to the colour-bar scale. An image of the foreground galaxy is underlaid for the purpose of visual orientation, including a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the MaNGA IFU.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4a.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672704/sty653fig4a.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4a.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672704\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig4a.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=CrQzOlIzpoWwTHKd7GqWPzHf9GajBGcAXZxf2TLyAmgKZy63Lgpqv9E6lZbANrsGBJBDrEfB75n-7g6GCt8h8onqeuc6MtfO~M4D6sNOy1EqPjMKzJ4E3x4OLwPPu1rOX5XhYk-VzUlmnuywQsCbQbfUF~mWRcNwNRrzh1GWQ1ByPdPgybmKtTFO7b-YzV-OU~ES0F~gV79rmq6Rqley7QIt8~JgrdlmR9qzz0IgCPLj4wcLUO6JpKbGjat0poq9vAF7IY7m-TleYPkrjOvjWTXaVDcBz2inepqZaJvxSt2EPvLNm-ZaA6CWtgUF7ytBtP4bkerblm9~upqBjGIFPQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=201672704&amp;ar=4925911&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4a.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig4b.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=2~OtEKlBRWkMaaY6-cZEfxCIdXMDa-ZV5yoMFf8XuP5dRhSEHTOsqkb~qCQW71OuRtESw1TNcwTfSdAGPrLedNDp9PgkxYDvGTPuAV8AQXhbZ~aATgv8J7vFTCme~T8AVC30eEMu2NKcZC6LqjSH5MiTHXlgAcXRgLQNLVEJ9v24Uh2r~~95dsd88~cn4mwUBt1wSIs0RhKrYS6Odt6U6Wd~JuNY5SPXqrGFXYZ3mAI0ZdJ4zbsVzZ02-eeOn~yxeX-zPA4qJBPTq9N2B6ZuvB5GbwGthVSMAN7oO9~I~2e668cEAEUI0wFL0~3yklwNX2nY4Pj-JSUVS0ff8bvR6Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Plots of background emission line hits for each SILO candidate. The positions of the hits are shown with cyan numbers representing the good hit count, and the cyan triangles show the location of the manually confirmed evidence of low S/N background emission-lines. The inner and outer radii of the cyan circle represent the lower and upper limits of the Einstein radius. The green coloured circle represents twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius, and thus the upper limit of the strong lensing regime. The value of the gravitational lensing convergence, \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3cr, according to equation (5), is plotted with squares with respect to the colour-bar scale. An image of the foreground galaxy is underlaid for the purpose of visual orientation, including a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the MaNGA IFU.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4b.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672704/sty653fig4b.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4b.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672704\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig4b.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=1V4XjF0z6uh~UC-QHOL8CFqoM~q2CuPFWJcfHlJUHho45SDAVeBECYkS5cPzo6HqZGho4YgXm~enRKws3mqW-E6XXeMkJGunAmm2HWyQ8ieup-U49-OoVBDsqjq-2ud6OM2G8OMbUaCinYawWfkd9avJ3u1VXfYcla0JzwjWh3YZEyBZ9oSNirCkMlnCe7aWjkv7hLTBmHFYFz9PkiyuQ11dKs6paZmIiQ8uWogn8stcsiL~z~d-N6EH69is~WBw8KOMwPhFp8mBxrOYENRsObDTpJ1BrGwe2OW9y~I61M~ubHxWJKtjBIPWbZ1kY-aH1vN4CXDk~nXp7GZEbuuQfA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=201672704&amp;ar=4925911&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4b.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig4c.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=zZo56PJzwolVKqqHDefZaxXvxiX7WNZMKUKuv~o01u3Eo6PTl-85-5ERTg2Y9GcbQx13p8ZFGhRWde2ZPZv8MeiJnDnTgEJt5uumLut4uVKlL44HXWtWxFdmFhUYCU5y6pTT-rzYREVKvZPiLoVSwzwmjKOLvMktmTVFhA6hQ2I0mtDr3JyY6RTkg-1mFoWG-fKRrRuqlwBJukuEigiEPw96RZUEgnP8Mf0g7kSQC2Wc7eND9FoE6ady94Z6LYg7nWOjgo3xykFWHPG4k0rxOSfi6LSFymmj7NKZlr-tJy7GJ~rDscN4yX316bi88NewnQm~1UGv5ZwBT2V0jnlpWw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Plots of background emission line hits for each SILO candidate. The positions of the hits are shown with cyan numbers representing the good hit count, and the cyan triangles show the location of the manually confirmed evidence of low S/N background emission-lines. The inner and outer radii of the cyan circle represent the lower and upper limits of the Einstein radius. The green coloured circle represents twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius, and thus the upper limit of the strong lensing regime. The value of the gravitational lensing convergence, \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3cr, according to equation (5), is plotted with squares with respect to the colour-bar scale. The positions of the hits are shown with cyan numbers representing the good hit count, and the cyan triangles show the location of the manually confirmed evidence of low S/N background emission-lines. The inner and outer radii of the cyan circle represent the lower and upper limits of the Einstein radius. The green coloured circle represents twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius, and thus the upper limit of the strong lensing regime. The value of the gravitational lensing convergence, \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3<sub>cr</sub>, according to equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ5\"></span><a href=\"#equ5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>), is plotted with squares with respect to the colour-bar scale. An image of the foreground galaxy is underlaid for the purpose of visual orientation, including a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the MaNGA IFU.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig4a.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=UtLxp2TFp26we-ie3WFsxRuS39m3v5LJVhlJ6shmZCIO9mQx0p0DsjRfPhdnZk6u70YBYQaVJCUdblHEbabykU-K9aziwn-v6e2-ZRy0-AsjA0CjUiXGyil13VWcScoQnnPaoE6OJ7nBoAt9N6ryd0T4DzDWARq4428ojyXs7fggOzwojDi2KKn1uF9RAZEgvQoZ6R9B~eJRgWVoOjktbeBYZjjHIGfj1ezJiHT~uHFD1zgrgU~VrrDbvGBV8qkJUm1bAaC-m9MbN7ziyW1oBKgilI4QRAXrkQsjKIQ30mDSZtqHwoBZljzQezYaeYqEHDdv77WBCiRbWj7ej~M-IQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Plots of background emission line hits for each SILO candidate. The inner and outer radii of the cyan circle represent the lower and upper limits of the Einstein radius. The green coloured circle represents twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius, and thus the upper limit of the strong lensing regime. The value of the gravitational lensing convergence, \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3cr, according to equation (5), is plotted with squares with respect to the colour-bar scale. An image of the foreground galaxy is underlaid for the purpose of visual orientation, including a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the MaNGA IFU.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4d.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672704/sty653fig4d.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4d.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672704\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig4d.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=TFFVMxquUQizNEwBvtbK1TM605J3KsM6ZNoBtMK3JNR5soz8K4w47WuBLsutAA69TC~wDFfLf4K6USMF3q3xg9k6vFl2Hg9bRtUc9L4zhGeee56twAHv46s951U-2Sy3KbaYxS61GRDfD~~H8bV~xlfOi7EF70TdLLGWKpBpRPN1Ohhf35W0gEpKW9-O4X0VQq40EnaP-z5s-QTDlt6V85luXreLyLM7mChguJJLNE8snaarETxNPb4vUpnWqX2o21N6CvtdgIYPwh0dEw-PBfGbKueopjsi3nIr2q1~7gaX0g4Ey8JbuMqJ6PCJxUU7tf5PDWwzp6J5~JvP25NIoQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=201672704&amp;ar=4925911&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4d.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig4e.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=G~YI1n2y5Xnw9APOVb9E1eI9776bHUNAHkGfQKLlBUzo-WyG4luNi7lDLFYty8W7ZKjNssdK6MXYWY72P8Qx4D4T83YHJVsGmUxP2RNOZhAGMGpK3AFUnU7zpmonkH6-ulJ90gPv9cU95h4yxRq3jfW3qIAZVMcixEOH6k6jvpPsVzlAApAy~PgbkPX6kssv4dKXSONBVa2ysGBBkOPOfgG8Wm-ybxTqVslQdky95PNO2D6rxfjHnA9yQNKSenvoXhKJIpsnongKzEuwER3wTlLQl74EUiO-i1T1KQj5WdShe1zdlkleUfv~8EHt-vKaXv3G5GJ4gtvPTD9DgbnhVA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Plots of background emission line hits for each SILO candidate. The positions of the hits are shown with cyan numbers representing the good hit count, and the cyan triangles show the location of the manually confirmed evidence of low S/N background emission-lines. The inner and outer radii of the cyan circle represent the lower and upper limits of the Einstein radius. The green coloured circle represents twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius, and thus the upper limit of the strong lensing regime. The value of the gravitational lensing convergence, \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3cr, according to equation (5), is plotted with squares with respect to the colour-bar scale. An image of the foreground galaxy is underlaid for the purpose of visual orientation, including a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the MaNGA IFU.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4e.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672704/sty653fig4e.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4e.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672704\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig4e.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=binOIJEeIGgQZrfLip6RELyGpw1BZj~ZNEvWMT9kXvOETlUyA6f-3QB9YlXbGOWnMkBybFytBYN7Wk27~gMdJyXafld3tayJnTEKbFUp8AB7SXKjTPoT0ugdMrlJz17PshujbYI-2zda-QNRvcfmeLk1Rv3bTfIwYcM8bvmdv6Tkd3wB5YcVywUZPb8CCDJJzm4uR9A5HT-5hs-Lk3nDScWz3qc5lKGfLeccG07S3tNNBsvxGd0SaUcIVv-JeRkcIslEij5cReqBNL4z7Z9wuxIu0RBT~bT2sznlIgjTZZcHq~Yh1yL7tW16il096mnUa23JKq0QRxpfUnU4iIOrBg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=201672704&amp;ar=4925911&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4e.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Plots of background emission line hits for each SILO candidate. The positions of the hits are shown with cyan numbers representing the good hit count, and the cyan triangles show the location of the manually confirmed evidence of low S/N background emission-lines. The inner and outer radii of the cyan circle represent the lower and upper limits of the Einstein radius. The green coloured circle represents twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius, and thus the upper limit of the strong lensing regime. The value of the gravitational lensing convergence, \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3<sub>cr</sub>, according to equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ5\"></span><a href=\"#equ5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>), is plotted with squares with respect to the colour-bar scale. An image of the foreground galaxy is underlaid for the purpose of visual orientation, including a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the MaNGA IFU.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201672705 id=\"201672705\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 NARROW-BAND LENSED IMAGE CONSTRUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the candidates have a spectroscopically determined background redshift, provided by <em>z</em><sub>B</sub> as listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, we are able to construct narrow-band images from the spectra. Although we do not generally have sufficient spatial resolution to identify gravitational lensing counter-images in all of the narrow-band images, we did serendipitously find some examples based on the following technique:</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using the background spectroscopic redshifts in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a>, we are able to construct narrow-band images around specific background emission-lines. In order to obtain smooth maps, we used the MaNGA DRP Cube files, which provided interpolated spectra for each spaxel (Law et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). To subtract the flux of the foreground galaxy, we fitted a model for each spaxel using the same method described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>. We summed each spaxel's residual flux within 4\u20138\u2009\u00c5 within the wavelengths of the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>a], and H\u2009\u03b1 background emission-lines. The two-dimensional maps of these combined narrow-band background emission-lines are plotted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"201672708\" scrollto-destination=\"201672708\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig5a.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=DSurmnvMTWcZf2UFdh1BLSj55ollC4PHllM7hc6F6nX8JklMsTdoXhCYmU9qZyRNeB4QriMUzgkAc4ac00J-YLgLYKVTo08crw41S6NywPGoEZBX9bXWdAPLYtEBqEvKij3ku1p95xbVa1VAO7Bak2qbaThQwdnYtRApWUR~C~Q17IerYH3L8xMETBx-sycQZjNNBgMYGquZ9kDKH5itmuuzR43skZK~K8jzA0h8lisDvznmZyM4KAbuWCZzM~12VKKpi2RZVvSrWvSdlV2HYsw5T8xRtfp8GxnJ9QG~7Cv5TqBEmvzRB-Whh07ZZ0lpYXz3KiaHXTv2Zx7rS9z~0A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Images of galaxies that show strong lensing features in narrow-band images. The left-hand panels shows the foreground galaxy (MaNGA target) produced by the MaNGA DRP( Law et\u00a0al. 2016). The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the target IFU. The right-hand panels shows the narrow-band image created by combining the flux of the [O\u2009ii], [O\u2009iiia], and H\u2009\u03b1 emission-lines within a \u00b14\u2009\u00c5\u2013\u00b18\u2009\u00c5 window at the redshift of the background source-plane, as described in Section\u00a04. High S/N detections are marked with cyan circles, and are likely images of background galaxies. Spaxels that show low S/N images or counter-images are marked with magenta crosses, and add support of strong lensing because they are in the same source-plane. Each panel displays a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The foreground and background redshifts are shown at the bottom left-hand panels and bottom right-hand panels, respectively. Panel (4) SDSS J1123+5111 is a possible compound lens, with two source-planes.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig5a.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672708/sty653fig5a.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig5a.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672708\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig5a.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=sQ6E2ae6KxZ-zc8u7JO2tT4nUxRaoh4Wz-~-kok7cG540lGsEEUpNSttujUYUSn8yW~XVRVd5tbN0cbpb4K09H3~KYaBrTNVhtA3QRYeMVXYfgIezB59VPMtouURGEA3N1anHP3RjG5OhQLttFObtvivqxj-~MTBpasxxaegQjuLNwhqzOVpffgmIAw1hA9SJlvDtkb2TllmZVIrcbDAFBDNogkLI4jr6YWwtApITJanaNZjlaQcV~Tc~qVrSzIRb5UumlHd9~Mo66KZecCQnp6S14y8OMIC4yMdkpqnUf1wXXPrjeB9XyeQvBDI6s7ZQHi0ZIVbqrnNli93Nu4Ilw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=201672708&amp;ar=4925911&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig5a.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig5b.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=Du9QF8khNwFcgmiqdvuxlbVeCCzaIsSB9Znwxn2Jh~07c2QXK0EVBrLLXmlDdU-L8Otcgi37UuhD2kdRSyKUiFQM8RCjVKgsui9YWoLK~qGDbRU0x~dSUCCW95CPIOj~l8iJqesjAxvfSYnvVaTjSjBzI9a8n3wT4xchXvhPRrfvfGZoCtUVkhd5~Pf4iU~vIKjrXhkiYfaqPiL7D~xOo-6BsYvUCEWGj~iaZ05TvFYpT79amsKfe-gg2tmLOnsYiH6JNuWRSrLsFxjH6qSxhSWEmAPTCKuRRG0~YwfXSLrCV3pgj-JOEox3fy5ej8CK2bg-CR0ktLnEwxwheg959Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Images of galaxies that show strong lensing features in narrow-band images. Each panel displays a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The foreground and background redshifts are shown at the bottom left-hand panels and bottom right-hand panels, respectively. Panel (4) SDSS J1123+5111 is a possible compound lens, with two source-planes.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig5b.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672708/sty653fig5b.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig5b.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672708\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig5b.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=HrnAmsJ0vFd~WyNwoCAFGXmQWF~X2FTG78EHOxMBXfwLyWT-U-R31jX8yyRSCs3mlyDPhyrRmdH8kzpkzF2I2wLbICH0jUuQPwgMEten5GVLb4-3lYtZudPbTy8rtMHQizmOg1x3gaE4gROP4ALXlDGOc16p7GkFnI3rdxl5s0-iiVuHMjauGHdm1bRCw-aoF8g66FWjNx7OXwMQQo6vbHlf3Fj4LwpXbsnk0CQiQiBVEzaq2rQ29KT61V2nFhRjI6l0r6XTZKwcUmwa0tTU5R~Lxuiskvdf-LAO0s1cwL0nT1GJtsWSAWwUEUqtLa5jZlZGAMeRfoXJg4mFtB~T4A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=201672708&amp;ar=4925911&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig5b.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Images of galaxies that show strong lensing features in narrow-band images. The left-hand panels shows the foreground galaxy (MaNGA target) produced by the MaNGA DRP( Law et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the target IFU. The right-hand panels shows the narrow-band image created by combining the flux of the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>a], and H\u2009\u03b1 emission-lines within a \u00b14\u2009\u00c5\u2013\u00b18\u2009\u00c5 window at the redshift of the background source-plane, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. High S/N detections are marked with cyan circles, and are likely images of background galaxies. Spaxels that show low S/N images or counter-images are marked with magenta crosses, and add support of strong lensing because they are in the same source-plane. Each panel displays a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The foreground and background redshifts are shown at the bottom left-hand panels and bottom right-hand panels, respectively. Panel (4) SDSS J1123+5111 is a possible compound lens, with two source-planes.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For most galaxies, the counter-image is near the foreground galaxy core. Although we have subtracted the foreground flux from the narrow-band images, the error in the residual flux is larger near the centre where the foreground is brightest whereas the counter-image is faint. Therefore, the chances to observe evidence of counter-images is small. Despite the challenges, we discovered eight candidates with counter-images shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. One of these systems, shown in Panel (4), is a compound lens candidate with two background source-planes, as further discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each galaxy in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, we indicate the positions (with cyan circles) of the high S/N detected background emission-lines that were visually inspected, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>. We manually inspected the source-plane for emission-lines that were otherwise too weak to be detected in the initial search, shown with magenta crosses in each spaxel.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although there are several sources of uncertainty in the construction of the narrow-band images, and follow-up imaging is required to confirm our interpretation, we observe the following lensing features, as described in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"201672712\" scrollto-destination=\"201672712\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Narrow-band inspection. This list identifies the strong lensing features observed within the narrow-band images from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. Column 1 presents the SDSS system name. Column 2 provides the manual inspection which identifies the strong lensing features.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>System name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Manual inspection<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>(1)<span .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SDSS J0733+4411\u00a0</td><td>Possible ring.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0825+1728\u00a0</td><td>Possible quad.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1120+4649\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1123+5111\u00a0</td><td>Candidate compound lens with two background source planes: image with a visible counter-image of an extended source, and a higher redshift image with a visible counter-image.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1307+4618\u00a0</td><td>Multiple images.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1436+4943\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1625+3952\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image. of high redshift background galaxy.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1701+3722\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image, confirming Smith (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>(1)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(2)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Manual inspection<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>(1)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(2)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SDSS J0733+4411\u00a0</td><td>Possible ring.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0825+1728\u00a0</td><td>Possible quad.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1120+4649\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1123+5111\u00a0</td><td>Candidate compound lens with two background source planes: image with a visible counter-image of an extended source, and a higher redshift image with a visible counter-image.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1307+4618\u00a0</td><td>Multiple images.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1436+4943\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1625+3952\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image. of high redshift background galaxy.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1701+3722\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image, confirming Smith (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201672712\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201672713 id=\"201672713\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 CANDIDATE MULTIPLE SOURCE-PLANE LENSES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Two of our candidate lenses show high S/N background emission-lines from distinct background source planes:</p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J0728+4005 listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> with foreground redshift <em>z</em><sub>F</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.04956, and shown in Panels 3a and 3b of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, with background redshifts <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.694 and <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.954,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J1123+5111 listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> with foreground redshift <em>z</em><sub>F</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.04865, and shown in Panels 17a and 17b of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> and Panel 4 of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, with background redshifts <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.165 and <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.264.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">The discovery of such systems is very rare but also of great scientific value due to having multiple Einstein radii to probe the mass distribution at distinct positions within the halo. Since the Einstein radius is a function of the angular diameter distance and the mass enclosed within the Einstein radius, these systems provide novel constraints on the total mass density profile of the lens (Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Collett &amp; Auger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The ratio of Einstein radii in multiple source-plane lenses is sensitive to cosmological parameters, but independent of the Hubble constant (Collett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Our candidates do not have optimal redshift configurations for constraining dark energy models with a constant equation of state, but they are potentially exciting probes of more complicated models of dark energy since low redshift compound lenses have a unique sensitivity to variations in the dark energy equation of state (Linder <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201672717 id=\"201672717\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We introduced the SILO survey, and presented a catalogue of 38 strong gravitational lens candidates discovered within the 2812 MaNGA galaxies released with SDSS-IV DR14, of which 8 have Grade-A lensing features visible in narrow-band images of the background source-plane. Out of the \u223c1.5 million MaNGA fibres, 698 exhibit background emission-lines above a threshold S/N allowing a partial reconstruction of the source-plane geometry. Two of these systems are compound lens candidates, one of which demonstrates lensing features visible within the narrow-band image.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">These SILO candidates complement previous SLACS, SWELLS, S4TM, BELLS, and BELLS GALLERY lenses by exploring the population of galaxies at smaller distances and larger Einstein radius. Follow-up imaging of these candidates could potentially confirm our interpretation of the detected background emission-lines within our estimated Einstein radii as strongly lensed images of more distant galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Combined with the stellar density maps, the lens models we obtain from follow-up imaging would generate mass profile parameters at positions with smaller <em>R</em>/<em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> than currently available. These additional constraints at small scales can be used to break the degeneracy between luminous and dark matter that currently plagues dynamical studies, and shed light on the bulge-halo conspiracy (Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Dutton &amp; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Shankar et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Lenses with a low <em>R</em>/<em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> ratio are particularly useful to obtain estimates (and possibly gradients) of the stellar initial mass function in the inner regions of massive galaxies, where the mass budget is dominated by the baryons (see e.g. Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; van Dokkum et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Because the SILO survey extends the spectroscopic discovery method of Bolton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>); Brownstein et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) to multiple IFU spectra, a follow-up imaging survey would provide validation of the source-plane distribution of lensing features and narrow-band images, which were used in the manual inspection process. This would allow us to refine our catalogue grading procedure. A further extension of the spectroscopic discovery method to include high-redshift Lyman-\u03b1 emitter source galaxies, following the procedure of the BELLS GALLERY survey (Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>), can be expected to increase the number of candidate lenses. Since MaNGA will observe a total of 10\u2009000 galaxies during SDSS-IV, we expect a large data base of background emission-lines, from which a catalogue of confirmed strong gravitational lenses would be constructed, which would ultimately be of great significance to many future studies.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201672722 id=\"201672722\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Funding for the SDSS IV has been provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science, and the Participating Institutions. The SDSS web site is <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.sdss.org\" target=\"_blank\">www.sdss.org</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS-IV is managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions of the SDSS Collaboration including the Brazilian Participation Group, the Carnegie Institution for Science, Carnegie Mellon University, the Chilean Participation Group, the French Participation Group, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, Instituto de Astrof\u00edsica de Canarias, The Johns Hopkins University, Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe (IPMU) / University of Tokyo, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Leibniz Institut f\u00fcr Astrophysik Potsdam (AIP), Max-Planck-Institut f\u00fcr Astronomie (MPIA Heidelberg), Max-Planck-Institut f\u00fcr Astrophysik (MPA Garching), Max-Planck-Institut f\u00fcr Extraterrestrische Physik (MPE), National Astronomical Observatories of China, New Mexico State University, New York University, University of Notre Dame, Observat\u00e1rio Nacional / MCTI, The Ohio State University, Pennsylvania State University, Shanghai Astronomical Observatory, United Kingdom Participation Group, Universidad Nacional Aut\u00f3noma de M\u00e9xico, University of Arizona, University of Colorado Boulder, University of Oxford, University of Portsmouth, University of Utah, University of Virginia, University of Washington, University of Wisconsin, Vanderbilt University, and Yale University.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This work was supported by World Premier International Research Center Initiative (WPI Initiative), MEXT, Japan. (SDSS-IV MaNGA Collaboration, 2018).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201672727 id=\"201672727\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">L. Moustakas and J. R. "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2018MNRAS.477..195T", "Tables status": "Complete", "Inspection status": "Incomplete", "Paper Overview": {"abstract": "We present a catalogue of 38 spectroscopically detected strong galaxy-galaxy gravitational lens candidates identified in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey IV (SDSS-IV). We were able to simulate narrow-band images for eight of them demonstrating evidence of multiple images. Two of our systems are compound lens candidates, each with two background source-planes. One of these compound systems shows clear lensing features in the narrow-band image. Our sample is based on 2812 galaxies observed by the Mapping Nearby Galaxies at APO (MaNGA) integral field unit (IFU). This Spectroscopic Identification of Lensing Objects (SILO) survey extends the methodology of the Sloan Lens ACS Survey (SLACS) and BOSS Emission-Line Survey (BELLS) to lower redshift and multiple IFU spectra. We searched \u223c1.5 million spectra, of which 3065 contained multiple high signal-to-noise ratio background emission-lines or a resolved [O ii] doublet, that are included in this catalogue. Upon manual inspection, we discovered regions with multiple spectra containing background emission-lines at the same redshift, providing evidence of a common source-plane geometry which was not possible in previous SLACS and BELLS discovery programs. We estimate more than half of our candidates have an Einstein radius \u2273 1.7 arcsec, which is significantly greater than seen in SLACS and BELLS. These larger Einstein radii produce more extended images of the background galaxy increasing the probability that a background emission-line will enter one of the IFU spectroscopic fibres, making detection more likely.", "start_page": "195", "authors": ["Talbot, Michael S.", "Brownstein, Joel R.", "Bolton, Adam S.", "Bundy, Kevin", "Andrews, Brett H.", "Cherinka, Brian", "Collett, Thomas E.", "More, Anupreeta", "More, Surhud", "Sonnenfeld, Alessandro", "Vegetti, Simona", "Wake, David A.", "Weijmans, Anne-Marie", "Westfall, Kyle B."], "issn": "0035-8711", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1803.03604", "Title": "SDSS-IV MaNGA: the spectroscopic discovery of strongly lensed galaxies", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "keywords": ["gravitational lensing: strong", "galaxies: general", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "volume": "477", "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2018MNRAS.477..195T", "end_page": "209", "number": "1", "publication_year": "2018/03/1", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/sty653", "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "author_address": ["AA(Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Utah, 115 S. 1400 E., Salt Lake City, UT 84112, USA), AB(Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Utah, 115 S. 1400 E., Salt Lake City, UT 84112, USA), AC(National Optical Astronomy Observatory 950 North Cherry Avenue, Tucson, AZ 85719, USA), AD(UCO/Lick Observatory, University of California, Santa Cruz, 1156 High St. Santa Cruz, CA 95064, USA), AE(PITT PACC, Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA 15260, USA), AF(Center for Astrophysical Sciences, Department of Physics and Astronomy, Johns Hopkins University, 3400 North Charles Street, Baltimore, MD 21218, USA), AG(Institute of Cosmology and Gravitation, University of Portsmouth, Dennis Sciama Building, Portsmouth, PO1 3FX, UK), AH(Kavli IPMU (WPI), UTIAS, The University of Tokyo, Kashiwa, Chiba 277-8583, Japan), AI(Kavli IPMU (WPI), UTIAS, The University of Tokyo, Kashiwa, Chiba 277-8583, Japan), AJ(Kavli IPMU (WPI), UTIAS, The University of Tokyo, Kashiwa, Chiba 277-8583, Japan), AK(Max-Planck-Institut f\u00fcr Astrophysik, Karl-Schwarzschild-Str. 1, D-85748 Garching, Germany), AL(School of Physical Sciences, The Open University, Milton Keynes, MK7 6AA, UK; Department of Physics, University of North Carolina, Asheville, NC 28804, USA), AM(School of Physics and Astronomy, University of St Andrews, North Haugh, St Andrews, KY16 9SS, UK), AN(UCO/Lick Observatory, University of California, Santa Cruz, 1156 High St. Santa Cruz, CA 95064, USA)"]}, "Action": "Scanned and processed all tables", "Status": "Complete", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/link_gateway/2018MNRAS.477..195T/PUB_HTML"}
=======

class=\"access-state-logos all-viewports\">\r\n                    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\">\r\n                <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main\">\r\n       <span>Article history</span><i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down arrow-icon\"></i>\r\n                </a>\r\n        </div>\r\n            <div class=\"history-entries-wrap 2018</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n                <div class=\"history-entry\">\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-state\">Revision received:</div>\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-date\">08 March 2018</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n                <div class=\"history-entry\">\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-state\">Accepted:</div>\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-date\">08 March 2018</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n                <div class=\"history-entry\">\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-state\">Published:</div>\r\n                    <div class=\"wi-date\">10 March 2018</div>\r\n                </div>\r\n        </div>\r\n</div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<script>\r\n    $(document).ready(function () {\r\n        $('.article-top-widget').on('click', '.ati-toggle-trigger', function () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleLinks widget-instance-OUP_Article_Links_Widget\">\n         \n    </div>\n\r\n\r\n        <div class=\"article-body js-content-body\">\r\n            <div class=\"toolbar-wrap js-toolbar-wrap\">\r\n                <div class=\"toolbar-inner-wrap\">\r\n                    <ul id=\"Toolbar\" role=\"navigation\">\r\n    <li class=\"toolbar-item item-pdf\">\r\n        <a class=\"al-link pdf article-pdfLink\" data-article-id=\"4925911\" href=\"/mnras/article-pdf/477/1/195/33025182/sty653.pdf\">\r\n            <img src=//oup.silverchair-cdn.com/UI/app/svg/pdf.svg alt=\"pdf\" /><span class=\"pdf-link-text\">PDF</span>\r\n        </a>\r\n    </li>\r\n                                                    <li class=\"toolbar-item item-link item-split-view\">\r\n                                <a href=\"javascript:;\"\r\n                                   class=\"split-view js-split-view st-split-view\"\r\n                                   target=\"\">\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-menu_split\"></i>\r\n                                    Split View\r\n                                </a>\r\n                            </li>\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item item-with-dropdown item-views\">\r\n                            <a class=\"at-views-dropdown class=\"toolbar-label\">\r\n                                    <div class=\"toolbar-text\">Views</div>\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down aria-label=\"submenu\">\r\n                                <div class=\"arrow-up\"></div>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\"               <li class=\"at-figures-tables article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"figures-tables\">\r\n                                    <a class=\"toolbar-item\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\" data-reveal><i class=\"icon-read-more\"></i><span>Cite</span></a>\r\n\r\n<div id=\"getCitation\" class=\"reveal-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <h3 class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>Michael S Talbot, Joel R Brownstein, Adam S Bolton, Kevin Bundy, Brett H Andrews, Brian Cherinka, Thomas E Collett, Anupreeta More, Surhud More, Alessandro Sonnenfeld, Simona Vegetti, David A Wake, Anne-Marie Weijmans, Kyle B Westfall,  SDSS-IV MaNGA: the spectroscopic discovery of strongly lensed galaxies, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 477, Issue 1, June 2018, Pages 195\u2013209, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/sty653\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/sty653</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n
