The inner and outer radii of the cyan circle represent the lower and upper limits of the Einstein radius. The green coloured circle represents twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius, and thus the upper limit of the strong lensing regime. The value of the gravitational lensing convergence, \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3cr, according to equation (5), is plotted with squares with respect to the colour-bar scale. An image of the foreground galaxy is underlaid for the purpose of visual orientation, including a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the MaNGA IFU.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4d.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672704/sty653fig4d.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4d.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672704\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig4d.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=TFFVMxquUQizNEwBvtbK1TM605J3KsM6ZNoBtMK3JNR5soz8K4w47WuBLsutAA69TC~wDFfLf4K6USMF3q3xg9k6vFl2Hg9bRtUc9L4zhGeee56twAHv46s951U-2Sy3KbaYxS61GRDfD~~H8bV~xlfOi7EF70TdLLGWKpBpRPN1Ohhf35W0gEpKW9-O4X0VQq40EnaP-z5s-QTDlt6V85luXreLyLM7mChguJJLNE8snaarETxNPb4vUpnWqX2o21N6CvtdgIYPwh0dEw-PBfGbKueopjsi3nIr2q1~7gaX0g4Ey8JbuMqJ6PCJxUU7tf5PDWwzp6J5~JvP25NIoQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=201672704&amp;ar=4925911&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4d.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig4e.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=G~YI1n2y5Xnw9APOVb9E1eI9776bHUNAHkGfQKLlBUzo-WyG4luNi7lDLFYty8W7ZKjNssdK6MXYWY72P8Qx4D4T83YHJVsGmUxP2RNOZhAGMGpK3AFUnU7zpmonkH6-ulJ90gPv9cU95h4yxRq3jfW3qIAZVMcixEOH6k6jvpPsVzlAApAy~PgbkPX6kssv4dKXSONBVa2ysGBBkOPOfgG8Wm-ybxTqVslQdky95PNO2D6rxfjHnA9yQNKSenvoXhKJIpsnongKzEuwER3wTlLQl74EUiO-i1T1KQj5WdShe1zdlkleUfv~8EHt-vKaXv3G5GJ4gtvPTD9DgbnhVA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Plots of background emission line hits for each SILO candidate. The positions of the hits are shown with cyan numbers representing the good hit count, and the cyan triangles show the location of the manually confirmed evidence of low S/N background emission-lines. The inner and outer radii of the cyan circle represent the lower and upper limits of the Einstein radius. The green coloured circle represents twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius, and thus the upper limit of the strong lensing regime. The value of the gravitational lensing convergence, \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3cr, according to equation (5), is plotted with squares with respect to the colour-bar scale. An image of the foreground galaxy is underlaid for the purpose of visual orientation, including a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the MaNGA IFU.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4e.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672704/sty653fig4e.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4e.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672704\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig4e.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=binOIJEeIGgQZrfLip6RELyGpw1BZj~ZNEvWMT9kXvOETlUyA6f-3QB9YlXbGOWnMkBybFytBYN7Wk27~gMdJyXafld3tayJnTEKbFUp8AB7SXKjTPoT0ugdMrlJz17PshujbYI-2zda-QNRvcfmeLk1Rv3bTfIwYcM8bvmdv6Tkd3wB5YcVywUZPb8CCDJJzm4uR9A5HT-5hs-Lk3nDScWz3qc5lKGfLeccG07S3tNNBsvxGd0SaUcIVv-JeRkcIslEij5cReqBNL4z7Z9wuxIu0RBT~bT2sznlIgjTZZcHq~Yh1yL7tW16il096mnUa23JKq0QRxpfUnU4iIOrBg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=201672704&amp;ar=4925911&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4e.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Plots of background emission line hits for each SILO candidate. The positions of the hits are shown with cyan numbers representing the good hit count, and the cyan triangles show the location of the manually confirmed evidence of low S/N background emission-lines. The inner and outer radii of the cyan circle represent the lower and upper limits of the Einstein radius. The green coloured circle represents twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius, and thus the upper limit of the strong lensing regime. The value of the gravitational lensing convergence, \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3<sub>cr</sub>, according to equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ5\"></span><a href=\"#equ5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>), is plotted with squares with respect to the colour-bar scale. An image of the foreground galaxy is underlaid for the purpose of visual orientation, including a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the MaNGA IFU.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201672705 id=\"201672705\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 NARROW-BAND LENSED IMAGE CONSTRUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Since the candidates have a spectroscopically determined background redshift, provided by <em>z</em><sub>B</sub> as listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, we are able to construct narrow-band images from the spectra. Although we do not generally have sufficient spatial resolution to identify gravitational lensing counter-images in all of the narrow-band images, we did serendipitously find some examples based on the following technique:</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using the background spectroscopic redshifts in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a>, we are able to construct narrow-band images around specific background emission-lines. In order to obtain smooth maps, we used the MaNGA DRP Cube files, which provided interpolated spectra for each spaxel (Law et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). To subtract the flux of the foreground galaxy, we fitted a model for each spaxel using the same method described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>. We summed each spaxel's residual flux within 4\u20138\u2009\u00c5 within the wavelengths of the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>a], and H\u2009\u03b1 background emission-lines. The two-dimensional maps of these combined narrow-band background emission-lines are plotted in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"201672708\" scrollto-destination=\"201672708\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig5a.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=DSurmnvMTWcZf2UFdh1BLSj55ollC4PHllM7hc6F6nX8JklMsTdoXhCYmU9qZyRNeB4QriMUzgkAc4ac00J-YLgLYKVTo08crw41S6NywPGoEZBX9bXWdAPLYtEBqEvKij3ku1p95xbVa1VAO7Bak2qbaThQwdnYtRApWUR~C~Q17IerYH3L8xMETBx-sycQZjNNBgMYGquZ9kDKH5itmuuzR43skZK~K8jzA0h8lisDvznmZyM4KAbuWCZzM~12VKKpi2RZVvSrWvSdlV2HYsw5T8xRtfp8GxnJ9QG~7Cv5TqBEmvzRB-Whh07ZZ0lpYXz3KiaHXTv2Zx7rS9z~0A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Images of galaxies that show strong lensing features in narrow-band images. The left-hand panels shows the foreground galaxy (MaNGA target) produced by the MaNGA DRP( Law et\u00a0al. 2016). The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the target IFU. The right-hand panels shows the narrow-band image created by combining the flux of the [O\u2009ii], [O\u2009iiia], and H\u2009\u03b1 emission-lines within a \u00b14\u2009\u00c5\u2013\u00b18\u2009\u00c5 window at the redshift of the background source-plane, as described in Section\u00a04. High S/N detections are marked with cyan circles, and are likely images of background galaxies. Spaxels that show low S/N images or counter-images are marked with magenta crosses, and add support of strong lensing because they are in the same source-plane. Each panel displays a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The foreground and background redshifts are shown at the bottom left-hand panels and bottom right-hand panels, respectively. Panel (4) SDSS J1123+5111 is a possible compound lens, with two source-planes.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig5a.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672708/sty653fig5a.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig5a.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672708\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig5a.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=sQ6E2ae6KxZ-zc8u7JO2tT4nUxRaoh4Wz-~-kok7cG540lGsEEUpNSttujUYUSn8yW~XVRVd5tbN0cbpb4K09H3~KYaBrTNVhtA3QRYeMVXYfgIezB59VPMtouURGEA3N1anHP3RjG5OhQLttFObtvivqxj-~MTBpasxxaegQjuLNwhqzOVpffgmIAw1hA9SJlvDtkb2TllmZVIrcbDAFBDNogkLI4jr6YWwtApITJanaNZjlaQcV~Tc~qVrSzIRb5UumlHd9~Mo66KZecCQnp6S14y8OMIC4yMdkpqnUf1wXXPrjeB9XyeQvBDI6s7ZQHi0ZIVbqrnNli93Nu4Ilw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=201672708&amp;ar=4925911&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig5a.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig5b.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=Du9QF8khNwFcgmiqdvuxlbVeCCzaIsSB9Znwxn2Jh~07c2QXK0EVBrLLXmlDdU-L8Otcgi37UuhD2kdRSyKUiFQM8RCjVKgsui9YWoLK~qGDbRU0x~dSUCCW95CPIOj~l8iJqesjAxvfSYnvVaTjSjBzI9a8n3wT4xchXvhPRrfvfGZoCtUVkhd5~Pf4iU~vIKjrXhkiYfaqPiL7D~xOo-6BsYvUCEWGj~iaZ05TvFYpT79amsKfe-gg2tmLOnsYiH6JNuWRSrLsFxjH6qSxhSWEmAPTCKuRRG0~YwfXSLrCV3pgj-JOEox3fy5ej8CK2bg-CR0ktLnEwxwheg959Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Images of galaxies that show strong lensing features in narrow-band images. Each panel displays a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The foreground and background redshifts are shown at the bottom left-hand panels and bottom right-hand panels, respectively. Panel (4) SDSS J1123+5111 is a possible compound lens, with two source-planes.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig5b.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672708/sty653fig5b.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig5b.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672708\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig5b.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=HrnAmsJ0vFd~WyNwoCAFGXmQWF~X2FTG78EHOxMBXfwLyWT-U-R31jX8yyRSCs3mlyDPhyrRmdH8kzpkzF2I2wLbICH0jUuQPwgMEten5GVLb4-3lYtZudPbTy8rtMHQizmOg1x3gaE4gROP4ALXlDGOc16p7GkFnI3rdxl5s0-iiVuHMjauGHdm1bRCw-aoF8g66FWjNx7OXwMQQo6vbHlf3Fj4LwpXbsnk0CQiQiBVEzaq2rQ29KT61V2nFhRjI6l0r6XTZKwcUmwa0tTU5R~Lxuiskvdf-LAO0s1cwL0nT1GJtsWSAWwUEUqtLa5jZlZGAMeRfoXJg4mFtB~T4A__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=201672708&amp;ar=4925911&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig5b.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Images of galaxies that show strong lensing features in narrow-band images. The left-hand panels shows the foreground galaxy (MaNGA target) produced by the MaNGA DRP( Law et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the target IFU. The right-hand panels shows the narrow-band image created by combining the flux of the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>], [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>a], and H\u2009\u03b1 emission-lines within a \u00b14\u2009\u00c5\u2013\u00b18\u2009\u00c5 window at the redshift of the background source-plane, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. High S/N detections are marked with cyan circles, and are likely images of background galaxies. Spaxels that show low S/N images or counter-images are marked with magenta crosses, and add support of strong lensing because they are in the same source-plane. Each panel displays a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The foreground and background redshifts are shown at the bottom left-hand panels and bottom right-hand panels, respectively. Panel (4) SDSS J1123+5111 is a possible compound lens, with two source-planes.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For most galaxies, the counter-image is near the foreground galaxy core. Although we have subtracted the foreground flux from the narrow-band images, the error in the residual flux is larger near the centre where the foreground is brightest whereas the counter-image is faint. Therefore, the chances to observe evidence of counter-images is small. Despite the challenges, we discovered eight candidates with counter-images shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. One of these systems, shown in Panel (4), is a compound lens candidate with two background source-planes, as further discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For each galaxy in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, we indicate the positions (with cyan circles) of the high S/N detected background emission-lines that were visually inspected, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>. We manually inspected the source-plane for emission-lines that were otherwise too weak to be detected in the initial search, shown with magenta crosses in each spaxel.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although there are several sources of uncertainty in the construction of the narrow-band images, and follow-up imaging is required to confirm our interpretation, we observe the following lensing features, as described in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl4\" data-open=\"tbl4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"201672712\" scrollto-destination=\"201672712\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl4\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl4\" data-id=\"tbl4\"><span class=\"label\">Table 4.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Narrow-band inspection. This list identifies the strong lensing features observed within the narrow-band images from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>. Column 1 presents the SDSS system name. Column 2 provides the manual inspection which identifies the strong lensing features.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>System name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Manual inspection<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>(1)<span .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SDSS J0733+4411\u00a0</td><td>Possible ring.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0825+1728\u00a0</td><td>Possible quad.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1120+4649\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1123+5111\u00a0</td><td>Candidate compound lens with two background source planes: image with a visible counter-image of an extended source, and a higher redshift image with a visible counter-image.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1307+4618\u00a0</td><td>Multiple images.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1436+4943\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1625+3952\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image. of high redshift background galaxy.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1701+3722\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image, confirming Smith (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>(1)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(2)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Manual inspection<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>(1)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(2)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SDSS J0733+4411\u00a0</td><td>Possible ring.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0825+1728\u00a0</td><td>Possible quad.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1120+4649\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1123+5111\u00a0</td><td>Candidate compound lens with two background source planes: image with a visible counter-image of an extended source, and a higher redshift image with a visible counter-image.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1307+4618\u00a0</td><td>Multiple images.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1436+4943\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1625+3952\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image. of high redshift background galaxy.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1701+3722\u00a0</td><td>Image with a isolated counter-image, confirming Smith (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201672712\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201672713 id=\"201672713\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 CANDIDATE MULTIPLE SOURCE-PLANE LENSES</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Two of our candidate lenses show high S/N background emission-lines from distinct background source planes:</p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J0728+4005 listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> with foreground redshift <em>z</em><sub>F</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.04956, and shown in Panels 3a and 3b of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>, with background redshifts <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.694 and <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.954,</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS J1123+5111 listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> with foreground redshift <em>z</em><sub>F</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.04865, and shown in Panels 17a and 17b of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> and Panel 4 of Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, with background redshifts <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.165 and <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.264.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">The discovery of such systems is very rare but also of great scientific value due to having multiple Einstein radii to probe the mass distribution at distinct positions within the halo. Since the Einstein radius is a function of the angular diameter distance and the mass enclosed within the Einstein radius, these systems provide novel constraints on the total mass density profile of the lens (Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Collett &amp; Auger <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The ratio of Einstein radii in multiple source-plane lenses is sensitive to cosmological parameters, but independent of the Hubble constant (Collett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Our candidates do not have optimal redshift configurations for constraining dark energy models with a constant equation of state, but they are potentially exciting probes of more complicated models of dark energy since low redshift compound lenses have a unique sensitivity to variations in the dark energy equation of state (Linder <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201672717 id=\"201672717\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 SUMMARY AND CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We introduced the SILO survey, and presented a catalogue of 38 strong gravitational lens candidates discovered within the 2812 MaNGA galaxies released with SDSS-IV DR14, of which 8 have Grade-A lensing features visible in narrow-band images of the background source-plane. Out of the \u223c1.5 million MaNGA fibres, 698 exhibit background emission-lines above a threshold S/N allowing a partial reconstruction of the source-plane geometry. Two of these systems are compound lens candidates, one of which demonstrates lensing features visible within the narrow-band image.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">These SILO candidates complement previous SLACS, SWELLS, S4TM, BELLS, and BELLS GALLERY lenses by exploring the population of galaxies at smaller distances and larger Einstein radius. Follow-up imaging of these candidates could potentially confirm our interpretation of the detected background emission-lines within our estimated Einstein radii as strongly lensed images of more distant galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Combined with the stellar density maps, the lens models we obtain from follow-up imaging would generate mass profile parameters at positions with smaller <em>R</em>/<em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> than currently available. These additional constraints at small scales can be used to break the degeneracy between luminous and dark matter that currently plagues dynamical studies, and shed light on the bulge-halo conspiracy (Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Dutton &amp; Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Shankar et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Lenses with a low <em>R</em>/<em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> ratio are particularly useful to obtain estimates (and possibly gradients) of the stellar initial mass function in the inner regions of massive galaxies, where the mass budget is dominated by the baryons (see e.g. Newman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>; van Dokkum et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Because the SILO survey extends the spectroscopic discovery method of Bolton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>); Brownstein et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) to multiple IFU spectra, a follow-up imaging survey would provide validation of the source-plane distribution of lensing features and narrow-band images, which were used in the manual inspection process. This would allow us to refine our catalogue grading procedure. A further extension of the spectroscopic discovery method to include high-redshift Lyman-\u03b1 emitter source galaxies, following the procedure of the BELLS GALLERY survey (Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>), can be expected to increase the number of candidate lenses. Since MaNGA will observe a total of 10\u2009000 galaxies during SDSS-IV, we expect a large data base of background emission-lines, from which a catalogue of confirmed strong gravitational lenses would be constructed, which would ultimately be of great significance to many future studies.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201672722 id=\"201672722\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" data-legacy-id=ack1>ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Funding for the SDSS IV has been provided by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, the U.S. Department of Energy Office of Science, and the Participating Institutions. The SDSS web site is <a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://www.sdss.org\" target=\"_blank\">www.sdss.org</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">SDSS-IV is managed by the Astrophysical Research Consortium for the Participating Institutions of the SDSS Collaboration including the Brazilian Participation Group, the Carnegie Institution for Science, Carnegie Mellon University, the Chilean Participation Group, the French Participation Group, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, Instituto de Astrof\u00edsica de Canarias, The Johns Hopkins University, Kavli Institute for the Physics and Mathematics of the Universe (IPMU) / University of Tokyo, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, Leibniz Institut f\u00fcr Astrophysik Potsdam (AIP), Max-Planck-Institut f\u00fcr Astronomie (MPIA Heidelberg), Max-Planck-Institut f\u00fcr Astrophysik (MPA Garching), Max-Planck-Institut f\u00fcr Extraterrestrische Physik (MPE), National Astronomical Observatories of China, New Mexico State University, New York University, University of Notre Dame, Observat\u00e1rio Nacional / MCTI, The Ohio State University, Pennsylvania State University, Shanghai Astronomical Observatory, United Kingdom Participation Group, Universidad Nacional Aut\u00f3noma de M\u00e9xico, University of Arizona, University of Colorado Boulder, University of Oxford, University of Portsmouth, University of Utah, University of Virginia, University of Washington, University of Wisconsin, Vanderbilt University, and Yale University.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This work was supported by World Premier International Research Center Initiative (WPI Initiative), MEXT, Japan. (SDSS-IV MaNGA Collaboration, 2018).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201672727 id=\"201672727\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\">L. Moustakas and J. R. This is the list of strong gravitational lens candidates, discovered in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span>3.2 that further demonstrated background emission-lines at a common redshift (source-plane) within the strong lensing regime as discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span>3.4. Column 1 provides the SDSS System Name in terms of truncated J2000 RA and Dec. in the format HHMMSS.ss\u00b1DDMMSS.s. A dagger represents if the candidate is displayed as a narrow-band image within this paper. Column 2 provides the Plate-IFU of the galaxy observation. Column 3 provides the foreground spectroscopic redshift defined as the mean inner spectroscopic redshift, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_\\mathrm{F} = {\\bar{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}}$|\u2060</span>, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span>3.1. Column 4 provides the spectroscopically detected background emission-line source redshift, <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>, computed as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span>3.4. Column 5 provides the NSA S\u00e9rsic effective radius. Column 6 provides the Einstein radius with upper and lower limits. Column 7 provides the number of good background emission-line hits identified within the common source-plane. For those source-planes with only a single hit, we distinguish the case from one multiline hit (identified by a \u2020) from the case of one single-line hit (identified by *). Column 8 provides the ratio of the radial distance of a source-plane image's detectable edge to the estimated upper limit of the Einstein radius.</p></div> </div><div class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/[XSLTSectionID][QueryString]\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Candidate strong gravitational lenses. This is the list of strong gravitational lens candidates, discovered in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span>3.2 that further demonstrated background emission-lines at a common redshift (source-plane) within the strong lensing regime as discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span>3.4. Column 1 provides the SDSS System Name in terms of truncated J2000 RA and Dec. in the format HHMMSS.ss\u00b1DDMMSS.s. A dagger represents if the candidate is displayed as a narrow-band image within this paper. Column 2 provides the Plate-IFU of the galaxy observation. Column 3 provides the foreground spectroscopic redshift defined as the mean inner spectroscopic redshift, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_\\mathrm{F} = {\\bar{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}}$|\u2060</span>, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span>3.1. Column 4 provides the spectroscopically detected background emission-line source redshift, <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>, computed as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span>3.4. Column 5 provides the NSA S\u00e9rsic effective radius. Column 6 provides the Einstein radius with upper and lower limits. Column 7 provides the number of good background emission-line hits identified within the common source-plane. For those source-planes with only a single hit, we distinguish the case from one multiline hit (identified by a \u2020) from the case of one single-line hit (identified by *). Column 8 provides the ratio of the radial distance of a source-plane image's detectable edge to the estimated upper limit of the Einstein radius.</p></div> </div><div .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sub>B</sub> (4)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>R</em><sub>eff</sub>(\u2009arcsec) (5)<span $('.article-top-widget').on('click', '.ati-toggle-trigger', function () {\r\n            $(this).find('.icon-general-add, .icon-minus').toggleClass('icon-minus icon-general-add');\r\n            $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"toolbar-label\">\r\n                                    <div class=\"toolbar-text\">Views</div>\r\n                                    <i class=\"icon-general-arrow-filled-down aria-label=\"submenu\">\r\n                                <div class=\"arrow-up\"></div>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"article-content\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Article contents</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"at-figures-tables article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"figures-tables\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Figures &amp; tables</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"video\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Video</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"audio\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Audio</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                                <li class=\"article-content-filter js-article-content-filter\" data-content-filter=\"supplementary-data\">\r\n                                    <a href=\"javascript:;\"><span>Supplementary Data</span></a>\r\n                                </li>\r\n                            </ul>\r\n                        </li>\r\n                        <li class=\"toolbar-item\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ToolboxGetCitation widget-instance-OUP_Get_Citation\">\n        <a href=\"#\" class=\"js-cite-button\" data-reveal-id=\"getCitation\" data-reveal><i class=\"icon-read-more\"></i><span>Cite</span></a>\r\n\r\n<div id=\"getCitation\" class=\"reveal-modal\" data-reveal>\r\n    <h3 class=\"modal-title\">Cite</h3>\r\n        <div class=\"oxford-citation-text\">\r\n            <p>Michael S Talbot, Joel R Brownstein, Adam S Bolton, Kevin Bundy, Brett H Andrews, Brian Cherinka, Thomas E Collett, Anupreeta More, Surhud More, Alessandro Sonnenfeld, Simona Vegetti, David A Wake, Anne-Marie Weijmans, Kyle B Westfall,  SDSS-IV MaNGA: the spectroscopic discovery of strongly lensed galaxies, <em>Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society</em>, Volume 477, Issue 1, June 2018, Pages 195\u2013209, <a href=\"https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/sty653\">https://doi.org/10.1093/mnras/sty653</a></p>\r\n        </div>\r\n\r\n       </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input
