class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201672637 id=\"201672637\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a catalogue of 38 spectroscopically detected strong galaxy\u2013galaxy gravitational lens candidates identified in the Sloan Digital Sky Survey IV (SDSS-IV). We were able to simulate narrow-band images for eight of them demonstrating evidence of multiple images. Two of our systems are compound lens candidates, each with two background source-planes. One of these compound systems shows clear lensing features in the narrow-band image. Our sample is based on 2812 galaxies observed by the Mapping Nearby Galaxies at APO (MaNGA) integral field unit (IFU). This Spectroscopic Identification of Lensing Objects (SILO) survey extends the methodology of the Sloan Lens ACS Survey (SLACS) and BOSS Emission-Line Survey (BELLS) to lower redshift and multiple IFU spectra. We searched \u223c1.5 million spectra, of which 3065 contained multiple high signal-to-noise ratio background emission-lines or a resolved [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet, that are included in this catalogue. Upon manual inspection, we discovered regions with multiple spectra containing background emission-lines at the same redshift, providing evidence of a common source-plane geometry which was not possible in previous SLACS and BELLS discovery programs. We estimate more than half of our candidates have an Einstein radius \u2273 1.7\u2009arcsec, which is significantly greater than seen in SLACS and BELLS. These larger Einstein radii produce more extended images of the background galaxy increasing the probability that a background emission-line will enter one of the IFU spectroscopic fibres, making detection more likely.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: general&quot;\">galaxies: general</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201672640 id=\"201672640\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Galaxy-scale strong gravitational lensing provides a unique probe into the cosmological distribution of matter, providing precision measurements of foreground galaxy surface mass densities from high-resolution lens models of observed multiple images (Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; Keeton, Kochanek &amp; Falco <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">b</a>; Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Brownstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Lagattuta et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Sonnenfeld et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>). When combined with other dynamical measurements, such as stellar kinematics, the mass distribution may be dissected into luminous and dark components (Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Dutton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Spiniello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Barnab\u00e8 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), including the detection of dark matter substructure within the lensing galaxies as well as small-mass dark matter haloes along their line of sight (Vegetti &amp; Koopmans <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Vegetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Cornachione et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>; Despali et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Dedicated surveys and serendipitous discoveries have to-date identified over 250 grade-A strong galaxy\u2013galaxy gravitational lenses<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup>, with foreground galaxy subtractions which exhibit multiple images of the same background galaxy with sufficient signal-to-noise ratio (S/N) to lead to a well-constrained lens model. Of the various methods, spectroscopic detection has proven to be the most successful means of discovery, with the Sloan Lens ACS (SLACS; Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>) survey, the Sloan WFC Edge-on Late-type Lens Survey (SWELLS; Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), the SLACS for the Masses (S4TM; Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) survey, the BOSS Emission-Line Lens Survey (BELLS; Brownstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), and the BELLS Galaxy-Ly\u03b1 Emitter systems (GALLERY; Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>) survey yielding a combined total of over 150 grade-A strong galaxy\u2013galaxy lenses, which were detected from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS; York et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>). All SDSS spectroscopic candidates required follow-up high-resolution <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em> (<em>HST</em>) imaging for confirmation of multiple background source images.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This manuscript introduces a new Spectroscopic Identification of Lensing Objects (SILO) survey based on the current SDSS-IV survey (Blanton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), extending the spectroscopic detection methods of Bolton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and Brownstein et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) to spectra obtained from the Mapping of Nearby Galaxies at APO (MaNGA; Bundy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) survey. Unlike BOSS and SDSS-I spectra, which were reduced from single fibres placed on each galaxy, MaNGA's Integral Field Unit (IFU; Drory et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Yan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>) places between 19 and 127 2\u2009arcsec fibres on each galaxy, covering a much larger field of view, between 12 and 32\u2009arcsec in diameter, with 15\u2009min dithered exposures repeated until the S/N above a threshold is achieved (Yan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016b</a>). MaNGA's six-year program targets \u223c10\u2009000 nearby (<em>z</em>\u00a0&lt;\u00a00.15) galaxies (Law et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) of which 2812 galaxies were included in Data Release 14 (DR14; SDSS Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Whereas SLACS, SWELLS, and S4TM surveys were based on SDSS-I galaxies with redshifts out to 0.45 (York et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) and BELLS and BELLS GALLERY surveys were based on SDSS-III BOSS galaxies with redshifts out to 0.7 (Eisenstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Dawson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), the typical MaNGA target redshift is <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.05. The majority of the MaNGA targets are selected using <em>i</em>-band absolute magnitude (M<sub><em>i</em></sub>)-dependent redshift cuts such that more luminous galaxies are selected at both preferentially higher redshift and over a larger volume than lower luminosity galaxies. The first of theses choices results in targets that cover the same range in angular effective radius (<em>R</em><sub>eff</sub>) irrespective of M<sub><em>i</em></sub>, and so all galaxies can be sampled to some multiple of <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> using the same size IFUs. The second produces a sample that has the same number density at all M<sub><em>i</em></sub>, i.e. the sample has the same number of the most luminous (massive) galaxies as the least luminous (massive) galaxies. Two main samples are defined. The Primary+ sample is selected so that galaxies have spectral coverage out to 1.5 <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> and makes up two thirds of the targets. The Secondary sample, making up the remaining third of the targets, is selected at slightly higher redshift than the Primary sample so that the galaxies have spectral coverage out to 2.5 <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub>. Full details of the MaNGA target selection can be found in Wake et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The discoveries presented in this manuscript are based on the MaNGA internal <span class=\"small-caps\">MPL-5</span> data release, which contains the same galaxies as in DR14. Whereas we have fewer galaxies in MaNGA than in the earlier lensing spectroscopic discovery programs, we have many more spectra for each individual galaxy, allowing the SILO detection algorithm to search for multiple background emission-lines with common background source redshifts. Furthermore, because the mean redshift of MaNGA (foreground) galaxies is <em>z</em>\u00a0\u223c\u00a00.05 with background galaxy redshifts up to the range of the previous surveys, the estimated Einstein radius is up to two to three times larger than those measured in the SLACS, SWELLS, S4TM, BELLS, and BELLS GALLERY surveys. Such large Einstein radii would not have been possible to detect with single fibre spectra because the background emission-lines of the magnified image of the source would have gone undetected since it would have landed outside the single fibre.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The larger Einstein radius is a measurement of the increased gravitational lensing strength, which produces more extended images of the background galaxy, thereby increasing the probability that a background emission-line will enter one of the IFU spectroscopic fibres, making detection more likely. This increases the overall probability that a galaxy of a given mass will be a strong gravitational lens. The multiple fibres with multiple exposures within the Einstein radius allow a correlation of the spectroscopic detections with their geometrical position across the IFU bundle. Using the individual best-fitting spectroscopic redshifts of detected background sources, we have extended the SILO algorithm to generate narrow-band images of the background source-plane, to allow for the first time, experimental predictions of images prior to follow-up imaging.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Shortly after the first MaNGA data release in 2016 (DR13; Albareti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>), which included 1351 galaxies, Smith (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) reported the discovery of a strong-lensing candidate, SDSS J170124.01+372258, at <em>z</em><sub>F</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.122. We also find this system as a promising lens candidate, based on our discovery of high S/N background emission-lines from a source at <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>\u00a0=\u00a00.790. The multiple images seen in the narrow-band images are geometrically positioned at the estimated Einstein radius and clearly show an arc and a counter-image separated by 3.7\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01.3\u2009arcsec.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">This paper is organized as follows. The expected number of lenses in MaNGA is presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>. The spectroscopic candidate discovery is presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>, consisting of foreground spectrum modelling (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>), background emission-line detection (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a>), Einstein radius estimation (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>), and source-plane inspection, with the discovery catalogue resulting from inspection (Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>). Lensed image construction, consisting of the discovery of counter-images in narrow-band images, is presented in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. Potential compound lenses containing two background galaxies along the same line of sight which were discovered in the catalogue are discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>. We provide a summary of results and conclusions on the importance of the SILO survey's MaNGA lens discovery program in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201672656 id=\"201672656\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 EXPECTED NUMBER OF LENSES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">We begin by presenting a crude estimate for the number of gravitational lenses expected to be detected in MaNGA. We make several simplifying assumptions. For instance, we assume that the lenses will be detected if the [<span class=\"small-caps\">Oii</span>] luminosity in the source is above a certain flux limit and we ignore the magnification boost provided by strong lensing. The probability that a given MaNGA galaxy with velocity dispersion \u03c3<sub><em>v</em></sub> at a redshift <em>z</em><sub>L</sub> will act as a lens for a source galaxy with flux brighter than <em>f</em> is then given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\r\n\\begin{eqnarray}\r\nP(z_{\\mathrm{L}}, \\sigma _v, f) = \\int n_{\\mathrm{S}}(z_{\\mathrm{S}}, z_{\\mathrm{L}}, f)\\, \\pi \\theta _\\mathrm{Ein}^2(\\sigma _v, z_{\\mathrm{L}}, z_{\\mathrm{S}}) \\frac{{\\rm d}V}{{\\rm d}z_{\\mathrm{S}}} {\\rm d}z_{\\mathrm{S}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <em>n</em><sub>S</sub> is the comoving source number density of [<span class=\"small-caps\">Oii</span>] galaxies at redshift <em>z</em><sub>S</sub> with an observed flux greater than <em>f</em> (which translates to a luminosity <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L&gt;4\\pi D_{\\rm L}^2 f$|</span> given the luminosity distance <em>D</em><sub>L</sub>), \u03b8<sub>Ein</sub> is the Einstein radius, given the lens and source redshifts, and d<em>V</em>/d<em>z</em><sub>S</sub> is the differential comoving volume at redshift <em>z</em><sub>S</sub>. We use the Schechter function fits to the [<span class=\"small-caps\">Oii</span>] luminosity function and its evolution (Khostovan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) to compute <em>n</em><sub>S</sub> and interpolate the redshift ranges in between. The Einstein radius is then given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\r\n\\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\theta _\\mathrm{Ein} = 4\\pi \\frac{\\sigma _{v}^2}{c^2} \\frac{D_{\\rm A}(z_{\\mathrm{L}}, z_{\\mathrm{S}})}{D_{\\rm A}(z_{\\mathrm{S}})},\r\n\\end{eqnarray}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>where, <em>c</em> is the speed of light, and <em>D</em><sub>A</sub>(<em>z</em><sub>L</sub>, <em>z</em><sub>S</sub>) and <em>D</em><sub>A</sub>(<em>z</em><sub>S</sub>) are the angular diameter distances between the lens and the source, and the source and observer, respectively. We used a fiducial value of \u03c3<sub><em>v</em></sub>\u00a0\u223c\u00a0200\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> for this coarse estimate.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">If we assume the [<span class=\"small-caps\">Oii</span>] flux limit to be 6\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>\u221217</sup>erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u2009\u00c5<sup>\u22121</sup>, we arrive at an estimate of \u223c60 lenses in the entire MaNGA survey. This estimate increases to \u223c200 lenses if the flux limit is reduced to 10<sup>\u221217</sup>erg\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009cm<sup>\u22122</sup>\u2009\u00c5<sup>\u22121</sup>. We have checked that accounting for the magnification bias changes the prediction by a factor of order unity. A fuller investigation into the biases of the lensing probability (e.g. Arneson, Brownstein &amp; Bolton <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) is in preparation.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=201672664 id=\"201672664\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 SPECTROSCOPIC CANDIDATE DISCOVERY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The premise behind the spectroscopic candidate selection of Bolton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and Brownstein et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) was to search for background emission-lines within the solid angle covered by the spectroscopic fibre (see also Warren et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Hewett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Willis, Hewett &amp; Warren <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Willis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We first summarize our approach for the lens search here and then describe each step in detail subsequently. The success of this discovery program hinges on a precise subtraction of a best-fitting foreground galaxy model. Although there are many residual features remaining in the spectrum after foreground galaxy subtraction, we limit our search for background emission-lines to high S/N features. We then use an upper limit on the Einstein radius for each galaxy, in order to determine which of our background emission-line regions were more likely strongly lensed images. Furthermore, because the background source-plane would occur at a common background redshift, and images of the background galaxy would be localized in a particular geometrical position in the IFU, a manual inspection process is required in order to grade the candidates for the final catalogue.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201672669 id=\"201672669\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-1>3.1 Foreground galaxy subtraction</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The fact that MaNGA galaxies are observed using the BOSS Spectrograph (Gunn et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Smee et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and that the row-stacked spectra (RSS) files generated by the MaNGA Data Reduction Pipeline (DRP; Law et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>) are equivalent to the BOSS and SDSS-I/II <span class=\"small-caps\">spec2d</span> reductions allows a very similar foreground galaxy model as was used in the SLACS (Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), SWELLS (Treu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), S4TM (Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), BELLS (Brownstein et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), and GALLERY (Shu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016a</a>) spectroscopic discovery programs. Whereas the BOSS and SDSS-I galaxies were observed with one fibre yielding a single spectrum containing all of the light from the galaxy, the MaNGA RSS files contain multiple spectra for each fibre, repeated across multiple exposures, yielding many spectra distributed at different positions over the galaxy. The wavelength calibration of the MaNGA data is accurate to 5\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> RMS, with a median spatial resolution of 2.54\u2009arcsec full width at half-maximum. This allows the candidate background emission-lines to be spatially correlated, increasing our confidence that the background emission-lines are real.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The galaxy model-fitting template requires a precise foreground redshift per fibre. Unlike the BOSS and SDSS-I/II reductions, the MaNGA DRP does not provide spectroscopic redshifts for each fibre. The MaNGA targeting NASA-Sloan Atlas (NSA; Albareti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) catalogue redshift is insufficiently precise to match each fibre's redshift due to the variations caused by the galaxy's radial velocity distribution. For each row (spectrum) in the RSS file, we computed the best-fitting spectroscopic redshift by running the publicly available BOSS pipeline <span class=\"small-caps\">spec1d \u2013 zfind</span> code (Bolton et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Because of the variation in the S/N, which decreases rapidly from the centre of the galaxy, we needed to make two passes to get good spectroscopic redshifts everywhere possible. The first pass computed spectroscopic redshifts using the provided value of the NSA catalogue redshift as the starting guess (prior) input to <span class=\"small-caps\">spec1d \u2013 zfind</span>. A mean spectroscopic redshift, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|${\\bar{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}}$|\u2060</span>, was then computed within the inner high S/N region, determined as the minimum radius at which the curvature became slowly varying as defined by |d<sup>2</sup>(S/N)/d<em>R</em><sup>2</sup>| \u2192 1, where S/N is the S/N. Redshifts that were more than 500\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup> from the mean were neglected as outliers. The second pass re-computed the spectroscopic redshifts in the low S/N region using the mean spectroscopic redshift as a prior. This method provided good spectroscopic redshifts throughout the galaxy, except in a minority of fibres, as shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, for example, galaxy, SDSS J083633.11+540229.27, with the mean spectroscopic <em>z</em>, shown by the blue-dashed line, very close to the NSA catalogue redshift, <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\r\n\\begin{eqnarray}\r\n{\\bar{z}} = 0.03052 \\sim z_{{\\rm nsa}} = 0.03046.\r\n\\end{eqnarray}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div></div>                        <a id=\"201672673\" scrollto-destination=\"201672673\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=axBPC3XxFyw3r2uCSob25iI6ypSCb-xw1WQNzDpcdv05O-~RKSdg7ls~GQ7qfX30G6cQAymv5vqCIXxCl87arRqcXPxJNY~Bu97vCziCyKpwnw0S3IsIevLcYqtsaWiU5ZRG43tRy174NZCyJ4qrx547DgLxnVn8Wzod0GqmU6upreNhXQcJ2KRIVvhz6OwEM4SN~NkEbDddlhxQI9n45p19MhEu39sB99Gd9NIUClDjOfIiBL-fQ1DyhpJsGJl~Oc68fA4bktXlQ8LaiF7~9zb0PhY5xX3GVGvA9D3TCPDmP1BV7XfbZCXnFHFKkiC1BRaYjnwCuM5WyWMkf3p9BA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The distribution of the mean S/N, shown in black solid-circles with respect to left-hand vertical axis, and best-fitting spectroscopic redshift, shown in open red-circles with respect to the right-hand vertical axis (as explained in Section\u00a03.1) for each spectrum, plotted as a function of the mean radial position (in arc-seconds) from the centre of the galaxy, shown for SDSS J0836+5402. The high S/N region is inside the mean inner radius, plotted as a vertical green-dotted line. The mean spectroscopic redshift is shown by the horizontal blued-dashed line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672673/sty653fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672673\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&Signature=C7SBE~K60Lmqh37v9ED1rcpUgs2ij2YYIsugYYUwPxU-AskBQJmWpVWr3q~r3nraAw43M765WyYYJ7V-WVn6TXdWafohU29M8ILOiKsw1~WFB1qRIjieZtCZq2vNcwfszzu846WRjdKxGHMVyM47NWNEjxyD14BmIcMz~WDKA6x26Go2c~GgDSA14qfNHadZvSjPJ95ImanHWDuAmsqa59CNP1s7yrMM8p0Lpe2JOKFt-LYUhihessDkz-1HR~aLYFJWOU847ehcS5rm-k0I3E0-Yo-k~UwyMVqQemhz9Fecc6aIOJZfjjPQewZhtbYnqX5sA5LM2nkPHv8Frws38Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201672673&ar=4925911&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The distribution of the mean S/N, shown in black solid-circles with respect to left-hand vertical axis, and best-fitting spectroscopic redshift, shown in open red-circles with respect to the right-hand vertical axis (as explained in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>) for each spectrum, plotted as a function of the mean radial position (in arc-seconds) from the centre of the galaxy, shown for SDSS J0836+5402. The high S/N region is inside the mean inner radius, plotted as a vertical green-dotted line. The mean spectroscopic redshift is shown by the horizontal blued-dashed line.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=axBPC3XxFyw3r2uCSob25iI6ypSCb-xw1WQNzDpcdv05O-~RKSdg7ls~GQ7qfX30G6cQAymv5vqCIXxCl87arRqcXPxJNY~Bu97vCziCyKpwnw0S3IsIevLcYqtsaWiU5ZRG43tRy174NZCyJ4qrx547DgLxnVn8Wzod0GqmU6upreNhXQcJ2KRIVvhz6OwEM4SN~NkEbDddlhxQI9n45p19MhEu39sB99Gd9NIUClDjOfIiBL-fQ1DyhpJsGJl~Oc68fA4bktXlQ8LaiF7~9zb0PhY5xX3GVGvA9D3TCPDmP1BV7XfbZCXnFHFKkiC1BRaYjnwCuM5WyWMkf3p9BA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The distribution of the mean S/N, shown in black solid-circles with respect to left-hand vertical axis, and best-fitting spectroscopic redshift, shown in open red-circles with respect to the right-hand vertical axis (as explained in Section\u00a03.1) for each spectrum, plotted as a function of the mean radial position (in arc-seconds) from the centre of the galaxy, shown for SDSS J0836+5402. The high S/N region is inside the mean inner radius, plotted as a vertical green-dotted line. The mean spectroscopic redshift is shown by the horizontal blued-dashed line.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig1.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672673/sty653fig1.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig1.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672673\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig1.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&Signature=C7SBE~K60Lmqh37v9ED1rcpUgs2ij2YYIsugYYUwPxU-AskBQJmWpVWr3q~r3nraAw43M765WyYYJ7V-WVn6TXdWafohU29M8ILOiKsw1~WFB1qRIjieZtCZq2vNcwfszzu846WRjdKxGHMVyM47NWNEjxyD14BmIcMz~WDKA6x26Go2c~GgDSA14qfNHadZvSjPJ95ImanHWDuAmsqa59CNP1s7yrMM8p0Lpe2JOKFt-LYUhihessDkz-1HR~aLYFJWOU847ehcS5rm-k0I3E0-Yo-k~UwyMVqQemhz9Fecc6aIOJZfjjPQewZhtbYnqX5sA5LM2nkPHv8Frws38Q__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201672673&ar=4925911&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig1.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">The distribution of the mean S/N, shown in black solid-circles with respect to left-hand vertical axis, and best-fitting spectroscopic redshift, shown in open red-circles with respect to the right-hand vertical axis (as explained in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>) for each spectrum, plotted as a function of the mean radial position (in arc-seconds) from the centre of the galaxy, shown for SDSS J0836+5402. The high S/N region is inside the mean inner radius, plotted as a vertical green-dotted line. The mean spectroscopic redshift is shown by the horizontal blued-dashed line.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In total, we obtained 158\u20092014 good spectroscopic redshifts for the spectra of the 2812 galaxies in MaNGA's internal <span class=\"small-caps\">MPL-5</span> data release. The mean inner spectroscopic redshift agreed with the NSA catalogue redshift to within 0.001 for 2750 of the 2812 galaxies. For each of these spectra, we constructed a best-fitting model spectrum to the galaxy continuum using a basis of seven principal component analysis (PCA) eigenspectra, and subtracted this continuum model from the data. Fibres which were at too low a S/N to yield a spectroscopic redshift were discarded from consideration in the search for background emission-lines.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201672678 id=\"201672678\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-2>3.2 Background emission-line detection</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to perform a systematic search for background emission-lines in each of the \u2273 1.5<em>M</em> residual spectra described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>, we reimplemented the original <span class=\"small-caps\">idl</span> based algorithms described in Bolton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and Brownstein et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) in a python-based software architecture including a back-end data base, and utilized the <span class=\"small-caps\">marvin</span> suite (Cherinka et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) to access MaNGA data including the web to visualize spectra and galaxy maps. Using a 500 cpu cluster, the residual spectra were scanned for at least two of the lines listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> detected at 4\u03c3; or a single line identified as a background [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>]\u03bb\u03bb\u20093727 detected at 6\u03c3. These are the values of the thresholds used in Bolton et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>) and Brownstein et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) for these two detection modes, referred to as \u2018multiline\u2019 and \u2018single-line\u2019 detections, respectively. Decreasing the threshold increases the number of candidate emission-line detections without necessarily increasing the number of candidates that pass inspection, whereas increasing the values of these thresholds decreases the number of candidates.</p>                        <a id=\"201672681\" scrollto-destination=\"201672681\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Emission-Line Wavelengths. Column 1 lists the emission-lines used in the spectroscopic discovery of background emission-line sources, and Column 2 shows the restframe vacuum wavelength of the emission-line. Column 3 provides the maximum redshift of the emission-line detectable with the BOSS spectrograph used by MaNGA.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Emission<span (\u00c5)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr><tr><th>(1)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(2)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(3)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>3727.09\u00a0</td><td>1.78\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>3729.88\u00a0</td><td>1.78\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>H\u03b4\u00a0</td><td>4102.89\u00a0</td><td>1.52\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>H\u03b3\u00a0</td><td>4341.68\u00a0</td><td>1.38\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>H\u03b2\u00a0</td><td>4862.68\u00a0</td><td>1.13\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>\u00a0</td><td>4960.30\u00a0</td><td>1.09\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>\u00a0</td><td>5008.24\u00a0</td><td>1.07\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>6549.86\u00a0</td><td>0.58\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>H\u03b1\u00a0</td><td>6564.61\u00a0</td><td>0.58\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>6585.27\u00a0</td><td>0.57\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>6718.29\u00a0</td><td>0.54\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>S\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>\u00a0</td><td>6732.68\u00a0</td><td>0.54\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201672681\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Detections that contained only an [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet were rejected if the [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet was located in a region near a sky emission-line. Multiline detections were modelled using a Gaussian, and detections that included both [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u20095007 and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>]\u20094959 emission-lines were scanned for a characteristic\u00a0\u223c\u00a03-to-1 ratio of the flux, respectively. All three multiline or greater hits were also visually inspected. Single-line detections were modelled with double Gaussian functions in order to scan for resolved [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublets. We inspected 1659 multiline \u2018hits\u2019 and 9762 single-line \u2018hits\u2019 that contained either the form of an [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet, or contained multiple patterns of background emission-lines. Each of these hits were graded as good. However, a large fraction of the single-line hits within a particular galaxy are not correlated in either redshift or spatially across the IFU and therefore drop out during the source-plane inspection process. Furthermore, detections that were geometrically positioned beyond the estimated strong lensing regime (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>) were discarded as non-candidates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We provide example plots of some of the multiline and single-line detections in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, showing the flux, best-fitting model, and Gaussian fits, including the observed emission-lines, as described in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"201672685\" scrollto-destination=\"201672685\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=mWiI5gl0Drtp0zUhW3pIKmkgO6999MxUCBIvQjspcpb3Jm9V93lSbaYR1SWJlhkkuzcbDQBfok3GkB8RE3-ax~cI0aPqR4RId~l5hS9ecXBBAVa-TNbegUpEAA92ZO8-teTHQaHOSHwLJTHPlzwo~bL6D87nlVFfBwPYnqIF7gN7lkdKGE88HDdgS335jKccXmL2P~eU9N8-vDrXQgpMJjg3DuKQuJdQPw4TfvHzYCms3qpV6vdEnASm2EpOl24UqJ4EC~b9fXikHiQJvynrRRrwyvofBx0itw13hRgI6ilqtKFOyZK6atYTmBalsZ4OvAfb5ziKXZwrHpUhFGkinQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Example plots of typical multiline and single-line detections. J1640+3919\u00a0</td><td>Single-line\u00a0</td><td>Resolved [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet.\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-modal\"><table><thead><tr><th>System name<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Detection mode<span aria-hidden=\"true\" aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(2)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>(3)<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>SDSS J1123+5111\u00a0</td><td>Multiline\u00a0</td><td>Resolved [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet, H\u03b1, H\u03b2, [N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>a], and [S\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>b].\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1307+4618\u00a0</td><td>Multiline\u00a0</td><td>Strong [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>a] and [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">iii</span>b] with a characteristic 3:1 ratio.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J0845+5357\u00a0</td><td>Multiline\u00a0</td><td>Resolved [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet, H\u03b1, and N\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>a.\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>SDSS J1640+3919\u00a0</td><td>Single-line\u00a0</td><td>Resolved [O\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">ii</span>] doublet.\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201672687\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As in previous discovery programmes (including SLACS and BELLS), these background emission-line detections provide compelling evidence that follow-up imaging will confirm the existence of strong gravitational lenses. But we can go farther in our inspection than was previously possible with the single spectroscopic observation of SDSS and BOSS, by combining an estimate of the Einstein radius, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>, with the geometric information with a source-plane inspection, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201672690 id=\"201672690\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-3>3.3 Einstein Radius Estimation</h3>\r\n<div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">MaNGA data allows us to use spatial information to classify our candidate lens systems. For strong lenses with a density profile close to isothermal, such as SLACS lenses (Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>), we expect strongly lensed images to lie within a circular region with radius equal to twice the Einstein radius of the lens. Although the most accurate measurement of the Einstein radius is derived by fitting a lens model to high-resolution imaging data, we do not have a complete set of follow-up imaging for our catalogue to model. Instead, we estimate the Einstein radius, using <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\r\n\\begin{eqnarray}\r\nR_{\\mathrm{Ein}} = \\sqrt{\\frac{4GM}{c^2}\\frac{D_{{\\rm LS}}}{D_{\\rm L} D_{\\rm S}}}\r\n\\end{eqnarray}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>where <em>M</em> is the enclosed mass, and <em>D<sub>L</sub></em> and <em>D<sub>S</sub></em> are cosmological angular diameter distances from observer to the lens and observer to the source, respectively.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The computation of the Einstein radius requires surface mass density maps for the galaxy, which we obtained from the publicly available MaNGA Firefly value-added catalogue (VAC, Wilkinson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) released with SDSS-IV DR14 (SDSS Collaboration et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). In this VAC the input stellar population models of Maraston &amp; Str\u00f6mb\u00e4ck (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>) are used, based on the MILES stellar library, with Kroupa IMF (Kroupa <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). We computed both a lower limit and an upper limit for the Einstein radius. For the lower limit of the Einstein radius, we computed the stellar mass enclosed within the lower-bound of the error provided by Firefly, but added no dark matter. For the upper limit, we computed the enclosed stellar mass within the upper-bound of the error provided by Firefly, and included a dark matter fraction computed using the theoretical model for the local stellar mass fraction of Jim\u00e9nez-Vicente et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>) at values of the ratio <em>R</em>/<em>R</em><sub>eff</sub>, where <em>R</em><sub>eff</sub> is the effective radius from the NSA catalogue. We computed the mass, <em>M</em>, enclosed within a distance, <em>R</em>, and the Einstein radius, <em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub>, iteratively using equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ4\"></span><a href=\"#equ4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>), until we obtained a <em>R</em>\u00a0=\u00a0<em>R</em><sub>Ein</sub> solution.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We compared the distribution of the Einstein radii of the SILO candidates to the published distribution of the Einstein radii of the grade A, B, and C lenses in the SLACS and BELLS surveys. As displayed in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, the Einstein radius distributions of the SLACS and BELLS surveys peak at \u223c0.6 and 1.0\u2009arcsec, with upper limits up to \u223c1.8 and 2.2\u2009arcsec, respectively. The distribution of the Einstein radii for the SILO candidates peaks at \u223c1.4 and 2.6\u2009arcsec, and the range extends up to \u223c3\u2009arcsec.</p>                        <a id=\"201672695\" scrollto-destination=\"201672695\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=0u7ll3kaCT15xqKCSZqCLYbAwnt7~TfVjNexsSK63TQadk~veTWcdHqr5aDYZWklJSANAW9rn18JW2JlGaV22mcCeQ0bef40L~aBT7c8jqUU4Wq-lYEsUhg53oriu9u02V76T8a9sRDBUoLh5iJRDGZp12hZwQfowgPcGBBCbxShskMq5vkl4npG4oq4XtkMynXIC8ghIIZKwYkgJq5Jw06OZKz0RjEQYCf40XUI4J7-YKSD4LZxAz3A9cc~aFOI6abRD9AkoWAOKQTrFSW-VLNmA9lAsAblXVJtQRIcXwTpQUtvCcypoFRZNIrPTp6GG99Q6x6BY4EiC2wfG3fRww__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of the Einstein radii. The grade A, B, and C lenses from the SLACS (large hatched region in purple) and the BELLS (small hatched region in green) surveys are compared with the Einstein radii of the lens candidates from the SILO survey (solid blue).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672695/sty653fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672695\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&Signature=bNNGYHBeSTNO6MCxny1X-XTzNHL~gndeDaopbCHZ8uhGRrJLGA6rdxKXcLbaN1T5afgbbdTCAS2m7aZz0NzDbff9gQ9-Ut4uLXSiZBPEGqfPkXhsoUhhxZ8yv5fj7ATLfNbyQGpdPNRKKoV20Wfq34IYcGsAUg4S01a0jz736e8mxWC0~yCkJzEAAaxWvznmW8hmsJozv5BiNvnJqYcVKQ8-~DM0EorXcMnjIOheBTifIdJtHjwjkvFg7g1whvGkxGgX0M4RQ3U~WT2GO9whJj-ggqj1GQbo9LewBkr05oXRWJyiGjNX0hLq-PrAucxce6cw0uysrAgb2ohcX~ufMg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201672695&ar=4925911&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of the Einstein radii. The grade A, B, and C lenses from the SLACS (large hatched region in purple) and the BELLS (small hatched region in green) surveys are compared with the Einstein radii of the lens candidates from the SILO survey (solid blue).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=0u7ll3kaCT15xqKCSZqCLYbAwnt7~TfVjNexsSK63TQadk~veTWcdHqr5aDYZWklJSANAW9rn18JW2JlGaV22mcCeQ0bef40L~aBT7c8jqUU4Wq-lYEsUhg53oriu9u02V76T8a9sRDBUoLh5iJRDGZp12hZwQfowgPcGBBCbxShskMq5vkl4npG4oq4XtkMynXIC8ghIIZKwYkgJq5Jw06OZKz0RjEQYCf40XUI4J7-YKSD4LZxAz3A9cc~aFOI6abRD9AkoWAOKQTrFSW-VLNmA9lAsAblXVJtQRIcXwTpQUtvCcypoFRZNIrPTp6GG99Q6x6BY4EiC2wfG3fRww__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Distribution of the Einstein radii. The grade A, B, and C lenses from the SLACS (large hatched region in purple) and the BELLS (small hatched region in green) surveys are compared with the Einstein radii of the lens candidates from the SILO survey (solid blue).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672695/sty653fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672695\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&Signature=bNNGYHBeSTNO6MCxny1X-XTzNHL~gndeDaopbCHZ8uhGRrJLGA6rdxKXcLbaN1T5afgbbdTCAS2m7aZz0NzDbff9gQ9-Ut4uLXSiZBPEGqfPkXhsoUhhxZ8yv5fj7ATLfNbyQGpdPNRKKoV20Wfq34IYcGsAUg4S01a0jz736e8mxWC0~yCkJzEAAaxWvznmW8hmsJozv5BiNvnJqYcVKQ8-~DM0EorXcMnjIOheBTifIdJtHjwjkvFg7g1whvGkxGgX0M4RQ3U~WT2GO9whJj-ggqj1GQbo9LewBkr05oXRWJyiGjNX0hLq-PrAucxce6cw0uysrAgb2ohcX~ufMg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=201672695&ar=4925911&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Distribution of the Einstein radii. The grade A, B, and C lenses from the SLACS (large hatched region in purple) and the BELLS (small hatched region in green) surveys are compared with the Einstein radii of the lens candidates from the SILO survey (solid blue).</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=201672696 id=\"201672696\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3-4>3.4 Source-plane inspection</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Whereas the BOSS and SDSS-I galaxies were observed with one fibre yielding a single spectrum containing all of the light from the galaxy, each MaNGA galaxy was observed with a fibre bundle, in which each fibre yielded multiple spectra from multiple exposures. This allows the candidate background emission-lines to be spatially correlated, increasing our confidence that the background emission-lines are real.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In order to determine whether the individual background emission-line hits discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a> originated in a common background source-plane, a finely spaced redshift grid (\u0394<em>z</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.05) was constructed and the hits for each galaxy were counted per spacing in the redshift grid. The background redshift, <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>, was selected from one of the good hits, limited to a precision of three decimal places, to allow for the variation due to internal radial motion of the background galaxy. Each MaNGA galaxy that contained at least two good hits in a source-plane was manually inspected to check for spatial correlation in the emission-line features. Since the background emission-lines in one hit can often be observed in surrounding fibres, we also inspected the source-planes that contained one good hit with three or more multilines, or one good single-line hit within a MaNGA galaxy that contained another source-plane with at least two good hits. These search methods identified a total of 1139 good multiline and 1926 good single-line hits, for a total of 3065. We inspected 397 background source-planes that contained at least two good hits. We inspected an additional 44 source-planes with a single multiline hit and 257 source-planes with a single-line hit.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The following selection criteria were applied to select the strong-lensing candidates from the source-planes:</p><ul class=\"roman-lower\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The source-plane contained at least one multiline hit with a minimum of three emission-lines, or</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Each source-plane contained at least two (single-line or multiline) hits, or</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The source-plane contained at least one (single-line or multiline) hit with additional evidence of low S/N emission-lines that are correlated with the source-plane redshift, and are contained within fibres that are positioned near the hit.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">The source-plane contained at least one background emission-line detected at a position within twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">We made an exception for system SDSS J0733+4411, SDSS J0825+1728, and SDSS J1307+4618, since each displayed well formed lensing features (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>). After applying these selections, we found 36 promising candidates out of which 2 showed evidence for compound lensing with multiple source-planes (see Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>). This final sample is presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"201672702\" scrollto-destination=\"201672702\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Candidate strong gravitational lenses. This is the list of strong gravitational lens candidates, discovered in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a> that further demonstrated background emission-lines at a common redshift (source-plane) within the strong lensing regime as discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>. Column 1 provides the SDSS System Name in terms of truncated J2000 RA and Dec. in the format HHMMSS.ss\u00b1DDMMSS.s. A dagger represents if the candidate is displayed as a narrow-band image within this paper. Column 2 provides the Plate-IFU of the galaxy observation. Column 3 provides the foreground spectroscopic redshift defined as the mean inner spectroscopic redshift, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_\\mathrm{F} = {\\bar{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}}$|\u2060</span>, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>. Column 4 provides the spectroscopically detected background emission-line source redshift, <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>, computed as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>. Column 5 provides the NSA S\u00e9rsic effective radius. Column 6 provides the Einstein radius with upper and lower limits. Column 7 provides the number of good background emission-line hits identified within the common source-plane. For those source-planes with only a single hit, we distinguish the case from one multiline hit (identified by a \u2020) from the case of one single-line hit (identified by *). Column 8 provides the ratio of the radial distance of a source-plane image's detectable edge to the estimated upper limit of the Einstein radius.</p></div> </div><div class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201672702\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Candidate strong gravitational lenses. This is the list of strong gravitational lens candidates, discovered in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.2</a> that further demonstrated background emission-lines at a common redshift (source-plane) within the strong lensing regime as discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>. Column 1 provides the SDSS System Name in terms of truncated J2000 RA and Dec. in the format HHMMSS.ss\u00b1DDMMSS.s. A dagger represents if the candidate is displayed as a narrow-band image within this paper. Column 2 provides the Plate-IFU of the galaxy observation. Column 3 provides the foreground spectroscopic redshift defined as the mean inner spectroscopic redshift, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z_\\mathrm{F} = {\\bar{z}_{\\mathrm{spec}}}$|\u2060</span>, as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.1</a>. Column 4 provides the spectroscopically detected background emission-line source redshift, <em>z</em><sub>B</sub>, computed as described in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-4\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.4</a>. Column 5 provides the NSA S\u00e9rsic effective radius. Column 6 provides the Einstein radius with upper and lower limits. Column 7 provides the number of good background emission-line hits identified within the common source-plane. For those source-planes with only a single hit, we distinguish the case from one multiline hit (identified by a \u2020) from the case of one single-line hit (identified by *). Column 8 provides the ratio of the radial distance of a source-plane image's detectable edge to the estimated upper limit of the Einstein radius.</p></div> </div><div J221101.52+122227.49\u00a0</td><td>7977\u20136102\u00a0</td><td>0.06139\u00a0</td><td>0.775\u00a0</td><td>12.06\u00a0</td><td><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$1.86_{-1.34}^{+0.28}$|</span>\u00a0</td><td>1*\u00a0</td><td>1.80\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/201672702\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> provides two-dimensional plots of each of these 36 candidate lenses, showing each of the above selection criteria including the positions of the high S/N emission-line hits, and the location of the manually confirmed evidence of low S/N emission-lines from the background source. The plots also show the upper limit of the Einstein radii and the colour-scale of the square markers indicates the gravitational lensing convergence, computed as <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ5\" content-id=\"equ5\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\r\n\\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\kappa = \\Sigma /\\Sigma _{{\\rm cr}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(5)</span></div>in order to indicate the strong lensing regime where \u03ba \u2273 1, where \u03a3 is the surface-mass density determined from the MaNGA Firefly VAC discussed in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3-3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3-3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3.3</a>, and <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ6\" content-id=\"equ6\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\">$$\r\n\\begin{eqnarray}\r\n\\Sigma _{{\\rm cr}} = \\frac{c^2}{4\\pi G} \\frac{D_{\\mathrm{S}}}{D_{\\mathrm{L}} D_{\\mathrm{L}S}}\r\n\\end{eqnarray}\r\n$$</div></div><span class=\"label\">(6)</span></div>is the critical surface-mass density.</div>                        <a id=\"201672704\" scrollto-destination=\"201672704\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig4a.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=UtLxp2TFp26we-ie3WFsxRuS39m3v5LJVhlJ6shmZCIO9mQx0p0DsjRfPhdnZk6u70YBYQaVJCUdblHEbabykU-K9aziwn-v6e2-ZRy0-AsjA0CjUiXGyil13VWcScoQnnPaoE6OJ7nBoAt9N6ryd0T4DzDWARq4428ojyXs7fggOzwojDi2KKn1uF9RAZEgvQoZ6R9B~eJRgWVoOjktbeBYZjjHIGfj1ezJiHT~uHFD1zgrgU~VrrDbvGBV8qkJUm1bAaC-m9MbN7ziyW1oBKgilI4QRAXrkQsjKIQ30mDSZtqHwoBZljzQezYaeYqEHDdv77WBCiRbWj7ej~M-IQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Plots of background emission line hits for each SILO candidate. The positions of the hits are shown with cyan numbers representing the good hit count, and the cyan triangles show the location of the manually confirmed evidence of low S/N background emission-lines. The inner and outer radii of the cyan circle represent the lower and upper limits of the Einstein radius. The green coloured circle represents twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius, and thus the upper limit of the strong lensing regime. The value of the gravitational lensing convergence, \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3cr, according to equation (5), is plotted with squares with respect to the colour-bar scale. An image of the foreground galaxy is underlaid for the purpose of visual orientation, including a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the MaNGA IFU.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4a.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672704/sty653fig4a.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4a.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672704\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig4a.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=CrQzOlIzpoWwTHKd7GqWPzHf9GajBGcAXZxf2TLyAmgKZy63Lgpqv9E6lZbANrsGBJBDrEfB75n-7g6GCt8h8onqeuc6MtfO~M4D6sNOy1EqPjMKzJ4E3x4OLwPPu1rOX5XhYk-VzUlmnuywQsCbQbfUF~mWRcNwNRrzh1GWQ1ByPdPgybmKtTFO7b-YzV-OU~ES0F~gV79rmq6Rqley7QIt8~JgrdlmR9qzz0IgCPLj4wcLUO6JpKbGjat0poq9vAF7IY7m-TleYPkrjOvjWTXaVDcBz2inepqZaJvxSt2EPvLNm-ZaA6CWtgUF7ytBtP4bkerblm9~upqBjGIFPQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=201672704&amp;ar=4925911&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4a.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig4b.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=2~OtEKlBRWkMaaY6-cZEfxCIdXMDa-ZV5yoMFf8XuP5dRhSEHTOsqkb~qCQW71OuRtESw1TNcwTfSdAGPrLedNDp9PgkxYDvGTPuAV8AQXhbZ~aATgv8J7vFTCme~T8AVC30eEMu2NKcZC6LqjSH5MiTHXlgAcXRgLQNLVEJ9v24Uh2r~~95dsd88~cn4mwUBt1wSIs0RhKrYS6Odt6U6Wd~JuNY5SPXqrGFXYZ3mAI0ZdJ4zbsVzZ02-eeOn~yxeX-zPA4qJBPTq9N2B6ZuvB5GbwGthVSMAN7oO9~I~2e668cEAEUI0wFL0~3yklwNX2nY4Pj-JSUVS0ff8bvR6Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Plots of background emission line hits for each SILO candidate. The positions of the hits are shown with cyan numbers representing the good hit count, and the cyan triangles show the location of the manually confirmed evidence of low S/N background emission-lines. The inner and outer radii of the cyan circle represent the lower and upper limits of the Einstein radius. The green coloured circle represents twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius, and thus the upper limit of the strong lensing regime. The value of the gravitational lensing convergence, \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3cr, according to equation (5), is plotted with squares with respect to the colour-bar scale. An image of the foreground galaxy is underlaid for the purpose of visual orientation, including a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the MaNGA IFU.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4b.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/201672704/sty653fig4b.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4b.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"201672704\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/sty653fig4b.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=1V4XjF0z6uh~UC-QHOL8CFqoM~q2CuPFWJcfHlJUHho45SDAVeBECYkS5cPzo6HqZGho4YgXm~enRKws3mqW-E6XXeMkJGunAmm2HWyQ8ieup-U49-OoVBDsqjq-2ud6OM2G8OMbUaCinYawWfkd9avJ3u1VXfYcla0JzwjWh3YZEyBZ9oSNirCkMlnCe7aWjkv7hLTBmHFYFz9PkiyuQ11dKs6paZmIiQ8uWogn8stcsiL~z~d-N6EH69is~WBw8KOMwPhFp8mBxrOYENRsObDTpJ1BrGwe2OW9y~I61M~ubHxWJKtjBIPWbZ1kY-aH1vN4CXDk~nXp7GZEbuuQfA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=201672704&amp;ar=4925911&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty653fig4b.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig4c.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=zZo56PJzwolVKqqHDefZaxXvxiX7WNZMKUKuv~o01u3Eo6PTl-85-5ERTg2Y9GcbQx13p8ZFGhRWde2ZPZv8MeiJnDnTgEJt5uumLut4uVKlL44HXWtWxFdmFhUYCU5y6pTT-rzYREVKvZPiLoVSwzwmjKOLvMktmTVFhA6hQ2I0mtDr3JyY6RTkg-1mFoWG-fKRrRuqlwBJukuEigiEPw96RZUEgnP8Mf0g7kSQC2Wc7eND9FoE6ady94Z6LYg7nWOjgo3xykFWHPG4k0rxOSfi6LSFymmj7NKZlr-tJy7GJ~rDscN4yX316bi88NewnQm~1UGv5ZwBT2V0jnlpWw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Plots of background emission line hits for each SILO candidate. The positions of the hits are shown with cyan numbers representing the good hit count, and the cyan triangles show the location of the manually confirmed evidence of low S/N background emission-lines. The inner and outer radii of the cyan circle represent the lower and upper limits of the Einstein radius. The green coloured circle represents twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius, and thus the upper limit of the strong lensing regime. The value of the gravitational lensing convergence, \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3cr, according to equation (5), is plotted with squares with respect to the colour-bar scale. The positions of the hits are shown with cyan numbers representing the good hit count, and the cyan triangles show the location of the manually confirmed evidence of low S/N background emission-lines. The inner and outer radii of the cyan circle represent the lower and upper limits of the Einstein radius. The green coloured circle represents twice the upper limit of the Einstein radius, and thus the upper limit of the strong lensing regime. The value of the gravitational lensing convergence, \u03ba\u00a0=\u00a0\u03a3/\u03a3<sub>cr</sub>, according to equation (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ5\"></span><a href=\"#equ5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a>), is plotted with squares with respect to the colour-bar scale. An image of the foreground galaxy is underlaid for the purpose of visual orientation, including a 5\u2009arcsec ruler at the top left-hand panels. The pink hexagon displays the field of view within the MaNGA IFU.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/477/1/10.1093_mnras_sty653/2/m_sty653fig4a.jpeg?Expires=1611466329&amp;Signature=UtLxp2TFp26we-ie3WFsxRuS39m3v5LJVhlJ6shmZCIO9mQx0p0DsjRfPhdnZk6u70YBYQaVJCUdblHEbabykU-K9aziwn-v6e2-ZRy0-AsjA0CjUiXGyil13VWcScoQnnPaoE6OJ7nBoAt9N6ryd0T4DzDWARq4428ojyXs7fggOzwojDi2KKn1uF9RAZEgvQoZ6R9B~eJRgWVoOjktbeBYZjjHIGfj1ezJiHT~uHFD1zgrgU~VrrDbvGBV8qkJUm1bAaC-m9MbN7ziyW1oBKgilI4QRAXrkQsjKIQ30mDSZtqHwoBZljzQezYaeYqEHDdv77WBCiRbWj7ej~M-IQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Plots of background emission line hits for each SILO candidate.
